</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Virginia has a total area of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>, including <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of water, making it the 35th-<a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_U.S._states_by_area&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of U.S. states by area (page does not exist)">largest state</a> by area.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">[6]</a></sup> Virginia is bordered by <a href="/wiki/Maryland" title="Maryland">Maryland</a> and <a href="/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a> to the north and east; by the <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean">Atlantic Ocean</a> to the east; by <a href="/wiki/North_Carolina" title="North Carolina">North Carolina</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tennessee" title="Tennessee">Tennessee</a> to the south; by <a href="/wiki/Kentucky" title="Kentucky">Kentucky</a> to the west; and by <a href="/wiki/West_Virginia" title="West Virginia">West Virginia</a> to the north and west. Virginia's boundary with Maryland and Washington, D.C. extends to the low-water mark of the south shore of the <a href="/wiki/Potomac_River" title="Potomac River">Potomac River</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup> The southern border is defined as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=36%C2%B030%27_parallel_north&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="36°30' parallel north (page does not exist)">36°&#160;30′ parallel north</a>, though surveyor error led to deviations of as much as three <a href="/wiki/Arcminute" title="Arcminute" class="mw-redirect">arcminutes</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup> The border with Tennessee was not settled until 1893, when <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virginia_v._Tennessee&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virginia v. Tennessee (page does not exist)">their dispute</a> was brought to the <a href="/wiki/U.S._Supreme_Court" title="U.S. Supreme Court" class="mw-redirect">U.S. Supreme Court</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Geology_and_terrain">Geology and terrain</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Virginia_painted_relief.png" title="File:Virginia painted relief.png">File:Virginia painted relief.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Virginia is divided into five geographic regions.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Chesapeake_Bay" title="Chesapeake Bay">Chesapeake Bay</a> separates the contiguous portion of the Commonwealth from the two-county peninsula of Virginia's <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Shore_of_Virginia" title="Eastern Shore of Virginia">Eastern Shore</a>. The bay was formed after the drowned river valleys of the <a href="/wiki/Susquehanna_River" title="Susquehanna River">Susquehanna River</a> and the <a href="/wiki/James_River" title="James River">James River</a> merged following a meteoroid <a href="/wiki/Chesapeake_Bay_impact_crater" title="Chesapeake Bay impact crater">impact crater</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Eocene" title="Eocene">Eocene</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-bay_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bay-10">[10]</a></sup> Many of <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_Virginia_rivers&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of Virginia rivers (page does not exist)">Virginia's rivers</a> flow into the Chesapeake Bay, including the <a href="/wiki/Potomac_River" title="Potomac River">Potomac</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rappahannock_River" title="Rappahannock River">Rappahannock</a>, <a href="/wiki/York_River_(Virginia)" title="York River (Virginia)">York</a>, and James, which create three peninsulas in the bay.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup> Geographically and geologically, Virginia is divided into five regions from east to west: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tidewater_region_of_Virginia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tidewater region of Virginia (page does not exist)">Tidewater</a>, <a href="/wiki/Piedmont_(United_States)" title="Piedmont (United States)">Piedmont</a>, <a href="/wiki/Blue_Ridge_Mountains" title="Blue Ridge Mountains">Blue Ridge Mountains</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ridge-and-Valley_Appalachians" title="Ridge-and-Valley Appalachians">Ridge and Valley</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Cumberland_Plateau" title="Cumberland Plateau">Cumberland Plateau</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-eov_13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eov-13">[13]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tidewater_(geographic_term)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tidewater (geographic term) (page does not exist)">Tidewater</a> is a <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_coastal_plain" title="Atlantic coastal plain">coastal plain</a> between the Atlantic coast and the <a href="/wiki/Fall_line" title="Fall line">fall line</a>. It includes the Eastern Shore and major <a href="/wiki/Estuary" title="Estuary">estuaries</a> of Chesapeake Bay. The Piedmont is a series of <a href="/wiki/Sedimentary_rock" title="Sedimentary rock">sedimentary</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Igneous_rock&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Igneous rock (page does not exist)">igneous rock</a>-based <a href="/w/index.php?title=Foothills&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Foothills (page does not exist)">foothills</a> east of the mountains which were formed in the <a href="/wiki/Mesozoic" title="Mesozoic">Mesozoic</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup> The region, known for its heavy clay soil, includes the <a href="/wiki/Southwest_Mountains" title="Southwest Mountains">Southwest Mountains</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-agriculture_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-agriculture-15">[15]</a></sup> The Blue Ridge Mountains are a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Physiographic_regions_of_the_world&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Physiographic regions of the world (page does not exist)">physiographic province</a> of the chain of <a href="/wiki/Appalachian_Mountains" title="Appalachian Mountains">Appalachian Mountains</a> with the highest points in the state, the tallest being <a href="/wiki/Mount_Rogers" title="Mount Rogers">Mount Rogers</a> at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup> The Ridge and Valley region is west of the mountains, and includes the <a href="/wiki/Great_Appalachian_Valley" title="Great Appalachian Valley">Great Appalachian Valley</a>. The region is <a href="/wiki/Carbonate_rock" title="Carbonate rock">carbonate rock</a> based, and includes <a href="/wiki/Massanutten_Mountain" title="Massanutten Mountain">Massanutten Mountain</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-regions_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-regions-17">[17]</a></sup> The Cumberland Plateau and the <a href="/wiki/Cumberland_Mountains" title="Cumberland Mountains">Cumberland Mountains</a> are in the south-west corner of Virginia, below the <a href="/wiki/Allegheny_Plateau" title="Allegheny Plateau">Allegheny Plateau</a>. In this region, rivers flow northwest, with a dendritic <a href="/w/index.php?title=Drainage_system_(geomorphology)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Drainage system (geomorphology) (page does not exist)">drainage system</a>, into the <a href="/wiki/Ohio_River" title="Ohio River">Ohio River</a> basin.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Shenandoah_green.jpg" title="File:Shenandoah green.jpg">File:Shenandoah green.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Deciduous and evergreen trees give the Blue Ridge Mountains their distinct color<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The state's carbonate rock is filled with more than 4,000 caves, ten of which are open for tourism.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup>
The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virginia_seismic_zone&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virginia seismic zone (page does not exist)">Virginia seismic zone</a> has not had a history of regular earthquake activity. Earthquakes are rarely above 4.5&#160;in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Richter_magnitude_scale&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Richter magnitude scale (page does not exist)">magnitude</a> because Virginia is located away from the edges of the <a href="/wiki/North_American_Plate" title="North American Plate">North American Plate</a>. The largest earthquake, at an estimated 5.9&#160;magnitude, was in 1897 near <a href="/wiki/Blacksburg,_Virginia" title="Blacksburg, Virginia">Blacksburg</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup> A <a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_Virginia_earthquake&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2011 Virginia earthquake (page does not exist)">5.8 magnitude earthquake</a> struck central Virginia on August 23, 2011, near <a href="/wiki/Mineral,_Virginia" title="Mineral, Virginia">Mineral</a>. The earthquake was reportedly felt as far away as <a href="/wiki/Toronto,_Canada" title="Toronto, Canada" class="mw-redirect">Toronto, Canada</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Atlanta,_Georgia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Atlanta, Georgia (page does not exist)">Atlanta, Georgia</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Florida&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Florida (page does not exist)">Florida</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Coal_mining_in_the_United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Coal mining in the United States (page does not exist)">Coal mining</a> takes place in the three mountainous regions at 40 distinct coal beds near Mesozoic basins.<sup id="cite_ref-mining_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mining-23">[23]</a></sup> Other resources such as <a href="/wiki/Slate" title="Slate">slate</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kyanite" title="Kyanite">kyanite</a>, sand, and gravel are mined, with an annual value of nearly $2&#160;billion <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Climate_chart&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Climate chart (page does not exist)">Template:Climate chart</a>
</p><p>The climate of Virginia becomes increasingly warmer and more humid farther south and east.<sup id="cite_ref-Burnham_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Burnham-25">[25]</a></sup> Seasonal extremes vary from average lows of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> in January to average highs of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> in July. The Atlantic ocean has a strong effect on eastern and southeastern coastal areas of the state. Influenced by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gulf_Stream&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gulf Stream (page does not exist)">Gulf Stream</a>, coastal weather is subject to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tropical_cyclone&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tropical cyclone (page does not exist)">hurricanes</a>, most pronouncedly near the mouth of Chesapeake Bay.<sup id="cite_ref-climatology_26-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-climatology-26">[26]</a></sup>
</p><p>Virginia has an annual average of 35–45 days of thunderstorm activity, particularly in the western part of the state,<sup id="cite_ref-tstorms_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tstorms-27">[27]</a></sup> and an average annual precipitation of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-climatology_26-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-climatology-26">[26]</a></sup> Cold air masses arriving over the mountains in winter can lead to significant snowfalls, such as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Blizzard_of_1996&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Blizzard of 1996 (page does not exist)">Blizzard of 1996</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Winter_storms_of_2009%E2%80%932010&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Winter storms of 2009–2010 (page does not exist)">winter storms of 2009–2010</a>. The interaction of these elements with the state's topography creates distinct <a href="/wiki/Microclimate" title="Microclimate">microclimates</a> in the Shenandoah Valley, the mountainous southwest, and the coastal plains.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup> Virginia averages seven <a href="/wiki/Tornado" title="Tornado">tornadoes</a> annually, most F2 or lower on the <a href="/wiki/Fujita_scale" title="Fujita scale">Fujita scale</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup>
</p><p>In recent years, the expansion of the southern suburbs of <a href="/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a> into <a href="/wiki/Northern_Virginia" title="Northern Virginia">Northern Virginia</a> has introduced an <a href="/wiki/Urban_heat_island" title="Urban heat island">urban heat island</a> primarily caused by increased absorption of solar radiation in more densely populated areas.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup> In the <a href="/wiki/American_Lung_Association" title="American Lung Association">American Lung Association</a>'s 2011 report, 11 counties received failing grades for air quality, with <a href="/wiki/Fairfax_County,_Virginia" title="Fairfax County, Virginia">Fairfax County</a> having the worst in the state, due to automobile pollution.<sup id="cite_ref-polution_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-polution-31">[31]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup> Haze in the mountains is caused in part by coal power plants.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Flora_and_fauna">Flora and fauna</span></h3>
<p>Forests cover 65% of the state, primarily with deciduous, broad leaf trees.<sup id="cite_ref-forests_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-forests-34">[34]</a></sup> Lower altitudes are more likely to have small but dense stands of moisture-loving hemlocks and mosses in abundance, with hickory and oak in the Blue Ridge.<sup id="cite_ref-Burnham_25-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Burnham-25">[25]</a></sup> However since the early 1990s, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gypsy_moth&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gypsy moth (page does not exist)">Gypsy moth</a> infestations have eroded the dominance of oak forests.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup> In the lowland tidewater yellow pines tend to dominate, with bald cypress wetland forests in the Great Dismal and Nottoway swamps. Other common trees and plants include chestnut, maple, <a href="/wiki/Liriodendron_tulipifera" title="Liriodendron tulipifera">tulip poplar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kalmia_latifolia" title="Kalmia latifolia">mountain laurel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Asclepias" title="Asclepias">milkweed</a>, daisies, and many species of ferns. The largest areas of wilderness are along the Atlantic coast and in the western mountains, where the largest populations of <a href="/wiki/Trillium_grandiflorum" title="Trillium grandiflorum">trillium wildflowers</a> in North America are found.<sup id="cite_ref-Burnham_25-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Burnham-25">[25]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup> The Atlantic coast regions are host to flora commonly associated with the South Atlantic pine forests and lower Southeast Coastal Plain maritime flora, the latter found primarily in southeastern Virginia.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Shenandoah_deer_20050521_191017_1.3008x2000.jpg" title="File:Shenandoah deer 20050521 191017 1.3008x2000.jpg">File:Shenandoah deer 20050521 191017 1.3008x2000.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">White-tailed deer, also known as Virginia deer, graze at Tanner Ridge in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Shenandoah_National_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Shenandoah National Park (page does not exist)">Shenandoah National Park</a></div></div></div>
<p>Mammals include <a href="/wiki/White-tailed_deer" title="White-tailed deer">White-tailed deer</a>, <a href="/wiki/American_black_bear" title="American black bear">black bear</a>, <a href="/wiki/Beaver" title="Beaver">beaver</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bobcat" title="Bobcat">bobcat</a>, <a href="/wiki/Coyote" title="Coyote">coyote</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Raccoon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Raccoon (page does not exist)">raccoon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Skunk" title="Skunk">skunk</a>, <a href="/wiki/Groundhog" title="Groundhog">groundhog</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virginia_Opossum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virginia Opossum (page does not exist)">Virginia Opossum</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gray_fox" title="Gray fox">gray fox</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Red_fox&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Red fox (page does not exist)">red fox</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Eastern_cottontail_rabbit&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Eastern cottontail rabbit (page does not exist)">eastern cottontail rabbit</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup> Other mammals include: nutria, fox squirrel, gray squirrel, flying squirrel, chipmunk,brown bat, and weasel. Birds include cardinals (the State Bird), barred owls, Carolina chickadees, Red-tailed Hawks, Ospreys, Brown Pelicans, Quail, Sea gulls, Bald Eagles, and Wild Turkeys. Virginia is also home to both the large and small piliated woodpecker as well as the common woodpecker. The <a href="/wiki/Peregrine_Falcon" title="Peregrine Falcon">Peregrine Falcon</a> was reintroduced into Shenandoah National Park in the mid-1990s.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup> Walleye, brook trout, Roanoke bass, and blue catfish are among the 210 known species of freshwater fish.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup> Running brooks with rocky bottoms are often inhabited by plentiful amounts of crayfish and salamanders.<sup id="cite_ref-Burnham_25-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Burnham-25">[25]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Chesapeake_Bay" title="Chesapeake Bay">Chesapeake Bay</a> is host to many species, including <a href="/wiki/Callinectes_sapidus" title="Callinectes sapidus">blue crabs</a>, clams, oysters, and rockfish (also known as striped bass).<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup>
</p><p>Virginia has 30 <a href="/wiki/National_Park_Service" title="National Park Service">National Park Service</a> units, such as <a href="/wiki/Great_Falls_Park" title="Great Falls Park">Great Falls Park</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Appalachian_Trail" title="Appalachian Trail">Appalachian Trail</a>, and one national park, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Shenandoah_National_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Shenandoah National Park (page does not exist)">Shenandoah National Park</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup> Shenandoah was established in 1935 and encompasses the scenic <a href="/wiki/Skyline_Drive" title="Skyline Drive">Skyline Drive</a>. Almost 40% of the park's area (79,579&#160;acres/322&#160;km<sup>2</sup>) has been designated as wilderness under the <a href="/w/index.php?title=National_Wilderness_Preservation_System&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="National Wilderness Preservation System (page does not exist)">National Wilderness Preservation System</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup> Additionally, there are 34 <a href="/wiki/List_of_Virginia_state_parks" title="List of Virginia state parks">Virginia state parks</a> and 17 <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_Virginia_state_forests&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of Virginia state forests (page does not exist)">state forests</a>, run by the Department of Conservation and Recreation and the Department of Forestry.<sup id="cite_ref-forests_34-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-forests-34">[34]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup> The Chesapeake Bay, while not a national park, is protected by both state and federal legislation, and the jointly run <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chesapeake_Bay_Program&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chesapeake Bay Program (page does not exist)">Chesapeake Bay Program</a> which conducts restoration on the bay and its watershed. The <a href="/wiki/Great_Dismal_Swamp_National_Wildlife_Refuge" title="Great Dismal Swamp National Wildlife Refuge">Great Dismal Swamp National Wildlife Refuge</a> extends into North Carolina, as does the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Back_Bay_National_Wildlife_Refuge&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Back Bay National Wildlife Refuge (page does not exist)">Back Bay National Wildlife Refuge</a>, which marks the beginning of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Outer_Banks&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Outer Banks (page does not exist)">Outer Banks</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:John_Smith_Saved_by_Pocahontas.jpg" title="File:John Smith Saved by Pocahontas.jpg">File:John Smith Saved by Pocahontas.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The story of <a href="/wiki/Pocahontas" title="Pocahontas">Pocahontas</a>, an ancestress of many of the <a href="/wiki/First_Families_of_Virginia" title="First Families of Virginia">First Families of Virginia</a>, was romanticized by later artists.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Jamestown_2007" title="Jamestown 2007">Jamestown 2007</a> marked Virginia's quadricentennial year, celebrating 400 years since the establishment of the Jamestown Colony. The celebrations highlighted contributions from <a href="/wiki/Native_Americans_in_the_United_States" title="Native Americans in the United States">Native Americans</a>, Europeans, and Africans, each of which had a significant part in shaping Virginia's history.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup> Warfare, including among these groups, has also had an important role. Virginia was a focal point in conflicts from the <a href="/wiki/French_and_Indian_War" title="French and Indian War">French and Indian War</a>, the <a href="/wiki/American_Revolution" title="American Revolution">American Revolution</a> and the <a href="/wiki/American_Civil_War" title="American Civil War">Civil War</a>, to the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=War_on_Terrorism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="War on Terrorism (page does not exist)">War on Terrorism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup> Stories about historic figures, such as those surrounding <a href="/wiki/Pocahontas" title="Pocahontas">Pocahontas</a> and <a href="/wiki/John_Smith_(explorer)" title="John Smith (explorer)">John Smith</a>, <a href="/wiki/George_Washington" title="George Washington">George Washington</a>'s childhood, or the plantation elite in the slave society of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Antebellum_Era_in_the_United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Antebellum Era in the United States (page does not exist)">antebellum period</a>, have also created potent myths of state history, and have served as rationales for Virginia's ideology.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Colony">Colony</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The first people are estimated to have arrived in Virginia over 12,000&#160;years ago.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup> By 5,000 years ago more permanent settlements emerged, and farming began by 900 AD. By 1500, the <a href="/wiki/Algonquian_peoples" title="Algonquian peoples">Algonquian peoples</a> had founded towns such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Werowocomoco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Werowocomoco (page does not exist)">Werowocomoco</a> in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tidewater_region_of_Virginia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tidewater region of Virginia (page does not exist)">Tidewater region</a>, which they referred to as <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tsenacommacah&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tsenacommacah (page does not exist)">Tsenacommacah</a></i>. The other major language groups in the area were the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Siouan_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Siouan languages (page does not exist)">Siouan</a> to the west, and the <a href="/wiki/Iroquoian_languages" title="Iroquoian languages">Iroquoians</a>, who included the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nottoway_Tribe&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nottoway Tribe (page does not exist)">Nottoway</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Meherrin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Meherrin (page does not exist)">Meherrin</a>, to the north and south. After 1570, the Algonquians consolidated under <a href="/wiki/Chief_Powhatan" title="Chief Powhatan">Chief Powhatan</a> in response to threats from these other groups on their trade network.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup> Powhatan controlled more than 30&#160;smaller tribes and over 150&#160;settlements, who shared a common <a href="/w/index.php?title=Powhatan_language&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Powhatan language (page does not exist)">Virginia Algonquian</a> language. In 1607, the native Tidewater population was between 13,000 and 14,000.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup>
</p><p>Several European expeditions, including a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ajac%C3%A1n_Mission&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ajacán Mission (page does not exist)">group of Spanish Jesuits</a>, explored the Chesapeake Bay during the 16th century.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup> In 1583, Queen <a href="/wiki/Elizabeth_I_of_England" title="Elizabeth I of England">Elizabeth I of England</a> granted <a href="/wiki/Walter_Raleigh" title="Walter Raleigh">Walter Raleigh</a> a charter to plant a colony north of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spanish_Florida&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Spanish Florida (page does not exist)">Spanish Florida</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup> In 1584, Raleigh sent an expedition to the <a href="/wiki/East_Coast_of_the_United_States" title="East Coast of the United States">Atlantic coast of North America</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup> The name "Virginia" may have been suggested then by Raleigh or Elizabeth, perhaps noting her status as the "Virgin Queen", and may also be related to a native phrase, "Wingandacoa", or name, "Wingina".<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup> Initially the name applied to the entire coastal region from South Carolina to Maine, plus the island of <a href="/wiki/Bermuda" title="Bermuda">Bermuda</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/London_Company" title="London Company">London Company</a> was incorporated as a joint stock company by the proprietary <a href="/wiki/Charter_of_1606" title="Charter of 1606">Charter of 1606</a>, which granted land rights to this area. The Company financed the first permanent English settlement in the "<a href="/w/index.php?title=New_World&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New World (page does not exist)">New World</a>", <a href="/wiki/Jamestown,_Virginia" title="Jamestown, Virginia">Jamestown</a>. Named for <a href="/w/index.php?title=James_I_of_England&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="James I of England (page does not exist)">King James I</a>, it was founded in May 1607 by <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Newport" title="Christopher Newport">Christopher Newport</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup> In 1619, colonists took greater control with an elected legislature called the <a href="/w/index.php?title=House_of_Burgesses&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="House of Burgesses (page does not exist)">House of Burgesses</a>. With the bankruptcy of the London Company in 1624, the settlement was taken into royal authority as an <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_England" title="Kingdom of England">English</a><a href="/wiki/Crown_colony" title="Crown colony">crown colony</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Colonial_Williamsburg_Governors_Palace_Front_Dscn7232.jpg" title="File:Colonial Williamsburg Governors Palace Front Dscn7232.jpg">File:Colonial Williamsburg Governors Palace Front Dscn7232.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Williamsburg,_Virginia" title="Williamsburg, Virginia">Williamsburg</a> was the capital from 1699 to 1780.</div></div></div>
<p>Life in the colony was perilous, and many died during the "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Starving_Time_(Jamestown)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Starving Time (Jamestown) (page does not exist)">starving time</a>" in 1609 and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Anglo-Powhatan_Wars&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Anglo-Powhatan Wars (page does not exist)">Anglo-Powhatan Wars</a>, including the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_massacre_of_1622&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indian massacre of 1622 (page does not exist)">Indian massacre of 1622</a>, which fostered the colonists' negative view of all tribes.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[60]</a></sup> By 1624, only 3,400&#160;of the 6,000&#160;early settlers had survived.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup> However, European <a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_commercial_tobacco_in_the_United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="History of commercial tobacco in the United States (page does not exist)">demand for tobacco</a> fueled the arrival of more settlers and servants.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Headright_system" title="Headright system" class="mw-redirect">headright system</a> tried to solve the labor shortage by providing colonists with land for each <a href="/wiki/Indentured_servant" title="Indentured servant">indentured servant</a> they transported to Virginia.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup> African workers were first imported to Jamestown in 1619 initially under the rules of indentured servitude. The shift to a system of African slavery was however pushed by the legal cases of <a href="/w/index.php?title=John_Punch_(slave)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="John Punch (slave) (page does not exist)">John Punch</a>, who was sentenced to lifetime slavery in 1640 for attempting to run away,<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup> and of <a href="/w/index.php?title=John_Casor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="John Casor (page does not exist)">John Casor</a>, who was claimed by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Anthony_Johnson_(colonist)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Anthony Johnson (colonist) (page does not exist)">Anthony Johnson</a> as his servant for life in 1655.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup> Slavery first appears in Virginia statues in 1661 and 1662, when a law made it hereditary based on the mother's status.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup>
</p><p>Tensions and the geographic differences between the working and ruling classes led to <a href="/wiki/Bacon%27s_Rebellion" title="Bacon's Rebellion">Bacon's Rebellion</a> in 1676, by which time current and former indentured servants made up as much as 80% of the population.<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[67]</a></sup> Rebels, largely from the colony's frontier, were also opposed to the conciliatory policy towards <a href="/w/index.php?title=Native_American_tribes_in_Virginia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Native American tribes in Virginia (page does not exist)">native tribes</a>. Colonists appropriated tribal land by force and treaty, including the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Treaty_of_1677&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Treaty of 1677 (page does not exist)">Treaty of 1677</a>, which made the signatory tribes <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tributary_state&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tributary state (page does not exist)">tributary states</a>. <a href="/wiki/Williamsburg,_Virginia" title="Williamsburg, Virginia">Williamsburg</a> became the colonial capital in 1699, following the founding of <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_College_of_William_%26_Mary&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The College of William &amp; Mary (page does not exist)">The College of William &amp; Mary</a> in 1693.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup> In 1747, a group of Virginian speculators formed the <a href="/wiki/Ohio_Company" title="Ohio Company">Ohio Company</a>, with the backing of the British crown, to start English settlement and trade in the <a href="/wiki/Ohio_Country" title="Ohio Country">Ohio Country</a> west of the <a href="/wiki/Appalachian_Mountains" title="Appalachian Mountains">Appalachian Mountains</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=France&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="France (page does not exist)">France</a>, which claimed this area as part of their colony of <a href="/wiki/New_France" title="New France">New France</a>, viewed this as a threat, and the ensuing <a href="/wiki/French_and_Indian_War" title="French and Indian War">French and Indian War</a> became part of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Seven_Years%27_War&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Seven Years' War (page does not exist)">Seven Years' War</a> (1756–1763). A militia from several British colonies, called the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virginia_Regiment&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virginia Regiment (page does not exist)">Virginia Regiment</a>, was led by then-Lieutenant colonel <a href="/wiki/George_Washington" title="George Washington">George Washington</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Statehood">Statehood</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Patrick_Henry_Rothermel.jpg" title="File:Patrick Henry Rothermel.jpg">File:Patrick Henry Rothermel.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">1851 painting of <a href="/wiki/Patrick_Henry" title="Patrick Henry">Patrick Henry</a>'s speech before the <a href="/w/index.php?title=House_of_Burgesses&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="House of Burgesses (page does not exist)">House of Burgesses</a> on the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virginia_Resolves&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virginia Resolves (page does not exist)">Virginia Resolves</a> against the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Stamp_Act_of_1765&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Stamp Act of 1765 (page does not exist)">Stamp Act of 1765</a></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_Great_Britain" title="Parliament of Great Britain">British Parliament's</a> efforts to levy new taxes following the <a href="/wiki/French_and_Indian_War" title="French and Indian War">French and Indian War</a> were deeply unpopular in the colonies. In the <a href="/w/index.php?title=House_of_Burgesses&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="House of Burgesses (page does not exist)">House of Burgesses</a>, opposition to <a href="/wiki/No_taxation_without_representation" title="No taxation without representation">taxation without representation</a> was led by <a href="/wiki/Patrick_Henry" title="Patrick Henry">Patrick Henry</a> and <a href="/wiki/Richard_Henry_Lee" title="Richard Henry Lee">Richard Henry Lee</a>, among others.<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup> Virginians began to <a href="/wiki/Committee_of_correspondence" title="Committee of correspondence">coordinate their actions</a> with other colonies in 1773, and sent delegates to the <a href="/wiki/Continental_Congress" title="Continental Congress">Continental Congress</a> the following year.<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup> After the House of Burgesses was dissolved by the royal governor in 1774, Virginia's revolutionary leaders continued to govern via the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virginia_Conventions&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virginia Conventions (page does not exist)">Virginia Conventions</a>. On May 15, 1776, the Convention declared Virginia's independence from the British Empire and adopted <a href="/wiki/George_Mason" title="George Mason">George Mason</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Virginia_Declaration_of_Rights" title="Virginia Declaration of Rights">Virginia Declaration of Rights</a>, which was then included in a new constitution.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup> Another Virginian, <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Jefferson" title="Thomas Jefferson">Thomas Jefferson</a>, drew upon Mason's work in drafting the national <a href="/wiki/United_States_Declaration_of_Independence" title="United States Declaration of Independence">Declaration of Independence</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-mason_74-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mason-74">[74]</a></sup>
</p><p>When the <a href="/wiki/American_Revolutionary_War" title="American Revolutionary War">American Revolutionary War</a> began, <a href="/wiki/George_Washington" title="George Washington">George Washington</a> was selected to head the <a href="/wiki/Continental_Army" title="Continental Army">colonial army</a>. During the war, the capital was moved to <a href="/wiki/Richmond,_Virginia" title="Richmond, Virginia">Richmond</a> at the urging of Governor Thomas Jefferson, who feared that Williamsburg's coastal location would make it vulnerable to British attack.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup> In 1781, the combined action of <a href="/wiki/Continental_Army" title="Continental Army">Continental</a> and French land and naval forces trapped the British army on the <a href="/wiki/Virginia_Peninsula" title="Virginia Peninsula">Virginia Peninsula</a>, where troops under George Washington and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Comte_de_Rochambeau&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Comte de Rochambeau (page does not exist)">Comte de Rochambeau</a> defeated British <a href="/w/index.php?title=General_Cornwallis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="General Cornwallis (page does not exist)">General Cornwallis</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Yorktown" title="Siege of Yorktown">Siege of Yorktown</a>. His surrender on October 19, 1781 led to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Peace_of_Paris_(1783)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Peace of Paris (1783) (page does not exist)">peace negotiations in Paris</a> and secured the independence of the colonies.<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">[76]</a></sup>
</p><p>Virginians were instrumental in writing the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Constitution" title="United States Constitution">United States Constitution</a>. <a href="/wiki/James_Madison" title="James Madison">James Madison</a> drafted the <a href="/wiki/Virginia_Plan" title="Virginia Plan">Virginia Plan</a> in 1787 and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States_Bill_of_Rights&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States Bill of Rights (page does not exist)">Bill of Rights</a> in 1789.<sup id="cite_ref-mason_74-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mason-74">[74]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virginia_Ratifying_Convention&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virginia Ratifying Convention (page does not exist)">Virginia ratified</a> the Constitution on June 25, 1788. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Three-fifths_compromise&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Three-fifths compromise (page does not exist)">three-fifths compromise</a> ensured that Virginia, with its large number of slaves, initially had the largest bloc in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States_House_of_Representatives&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States House of Representatives (page does not exist)">House of Representatives</a>. Together with the <a href="/wiki/Virginia_dynasty" title="Virginia dynasty">Virginia dynasty</a> of presidents, this gave the Commonwealth national importance. In 1790, both Virginia and Maryland ceded territory to form the new <a href="/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">District of Columbia</a>, though the Virginian area was <a href="/wiki/District_of_Columbia_retrocession" title="District of Columbia retrocession">retroceded</a> in 1846.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup> Virginia is called "Mother of States" because of its role in being carved into states like <a href="/wiki/Kentucky" title="Kentucky">Kentucky</a>, which became the 15th state in 1792, and for the numbers of <a href="/w/index.php?title=American_pioneer&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="American pioneer (page does not exist)">American pioneers</a> born in Virginia.<sup id="cite_ref-Robertson_78-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Robertson-78">[78]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Civil_War_and_aftermath">Civil War and aftermath</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Union_soldiers_entrenched_along_the_west_bank_of_the_Rappahannock_River_at_Fredericksburg,_Virginia_(111-B-157).jpg" title="File:Union soldiers entrenched along the west bank of the Rappahannock River at Fredericksburg, Virginia (111-B-157).jpg">File:Union soldiers entrenched along the west bank of the Rappahannock River at Fredericksburg, Virginia (111-B-157).jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Union soldiers before Marye's Heights, <a href="/wiki/Second_Battle_of_Fredericksburg" title="Second Battle of Fredericksburg">Fredericksburg</a>, May 1863</div></div></div>
<p>In addition to agriculture, slave labor was increasingly used in mining, shipbuilding and other industries.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[79]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nat_Turner%27s_slave_rebellion&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nat Turner's slave rebellion (page does not exist)">Nat Turner's slave rebellion</a> in 1831 and <a href="/w/index.php?title=John_Brown%27s_Raid_on_Harpers_Ferry&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="John Brown's Raid on Harpers Ferry (page does not exist)">John Brown's Raid on Harpers Ferry</a> in 1859 showed deep social discontent about slavery and its role in the <a href="/wiki/Plantation_economy" title="Plantation economy">plantation economy</a>. By 1860, almost half a million people, roughly 31% of the total population of Virginia, were enslaved.<sup id="cite_ref-hc_80-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hc-80">[80]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup> This division contributed to the start of the <a href="/wiki/American_Civil_War" title="American Civil War">American Civil War</a>.
</p><p>Virginia voted to secede from the United States on April 17, 1861, after the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Fort_Sumter" title="Battle of Fort Sumter">Battle of Fort Sumter</a> and <a href="/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln" title="Abraham Lincoln">Abraham Lincoln</a>'s call for volunteers. On April 24, Virginia joined the <a href="/wiki/Confederate_States_of_America" title="Confederate States of America">Confederate States of America</a>, which chose Richmond as its capital.<sup id="cite_ref-Robertson_78-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Robertson-78">[78]</a></sup> After the 1861 <a href="/wiki/Wheeling_Convention" title="Wheeling Convention">Wheeling Convention</a>, 48 counties in the northwest separated to form a new state of <a href="/wiki/West_Virginia" title="West Virginia">West Virginia</a>, which chose to remain loyal to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Union_(Civil_War)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Union (Civil War) (page does not exist)">Union</a>. Virginian general <a href="/wiki/Robert_E._Lee" title="Robert E. Lee">Robert E. Lee</a> took command of the <a href="/wiki/Army_of_Northern_Virginia" title="Army of Northern Virginia">Army of Northern Virginia</a> in 1862, and led invasions into Union territory, ultimately becoming commander of all Confederate forces. During the war, more battles were fought in Virginia than anywhere else, including <a href="/wiki/First_Battle_of_Bull_Run" title="First Battle of Bull Run">Bull Run</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Seven_Days_Battles" title="Seven Days Battles">Seven Days Battles</a>, <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Chancellorsville" title="Battle of Chancellorsville">Chancellorsville</a>, and the concluding <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Appomattox_Court_House" title="Battle of Appomattox Court House">Battle of Appomattox Court House</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[82]</a></sup> After the <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Petersburg" title="Siege of Petersburg">capture of Richmond</a> in April 1865, the state capital was briefly moved to <a href="/wiki/Lynchburg,_Virginia" title="Lynchburg, Virginia">Lynchburg</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup> while the confederate leadership fled to <a href="/wiki/Danville,_Virginia" title="Danville, Virginia">Danville</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[84]</a></sup> Virginia was formally restored to the United States in 1870, due to the work of the <a href="/wiki/Committee_of_Nine" title="Committee of Nine">Committee of Nine</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the post-war <a href="/w/index.php?title=Reconstruction_era_of_the_United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Reconstruction era of the United States (page does not exist)">Reconstruction era</a>, Virginia adopted a constitution which provided for free public schools, and guaranteed political, civil, and <a href="/wiki/Voting_rights_in_the_United_States" title="Voting rights in the United States">voting rights</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[86]</a></sup> The populist <a href="/wiki/Readjuster_Party" title="Readjuster Party">Readjuster Party</a> ran an inclusive coalition until the conservative white <a href="/w/index.php?title=Democratic_Party_of_Virginia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Democratic Party of Virginia (page does not exist)">Democratic Party</a> gained power after 1883.<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[87]</a></sup> It passed segregationist <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jim_Crow_laws&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jim Crow laws (page does not exist)">Jim Crow laws</a> and in 1902 rewrote the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Virginia" title="Constitution of Virginia">Constitution of Virginia</a> to include a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Poll_tax&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Poll tax (page does not exist)">poll tax</a> and other voter registration measures that effectively <a href="/w/index.php?title=Disfranchisement_after_the_Civil_War&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Disfranchisement after the Civil War (page does not exist)">disfranchised</a> most African Americans and many poor whites.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">[88]</a></sup> Though their schools and public services were segregated and underfunded due to a lack of political representation, African Americans were able to unite in communities and take a greater roll in Virginia society.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">[89]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Modern_era">Modern era</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:USS_Virginia_in_port.jpg" title="File:USS Virginia in port.jpg">File:USS Virginia in port.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Many <a href="/wiki/Pre-Dreadnought" title="Pre-Dreadnought" class="mw-redirect">Pre-Dreadnought</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_War_I&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World War I (page does not exist)">World War I</a>-era warships were built in <a href="/wiki/Newport_News,_Virginia" title="Newport News, Virginia">Newport News</a>, including the <a href="/wiki/USS_Virginia_(BB-13)" title="USS Virginia (BB-13)">USS <i>Virginia</i></a>.</div></div></div>
<p>New economic forces also changed the Commonwealth. Virginian <a href="/wiki/James_Albert_Bonsack" title="James Albert Bonsack">James Albert Bonsack</a> invented the tobacco cigarette rolling machine in 1880 leading to new industrial scale production centered around Richmond. In 1886, railroad magnate <a href="/wiki/Collis_Potter_Huntington" title="Collis Potter Huntington">Collis Potter Huntington</a> founded <a href="/wiki/Newport_News_Shipbuilding" title="Newport News Shipbuilding">Newport News Shipbuilding</a>, which was responsible for building six major <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_War_I&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World War I (page does not exist)">World War I</a>-era battleships for the <a href="/wiki/U.S._Navy" title="U.S. Navy" class="mw-redirect">U.S. Navy</a> from 1907–1923.<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup> During the war, <a href="/wiki/German_Empire" title="German Empire">German</a> submarines like <a href="/w/index.php?title=SM_U-151&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="SM U-151 (page does not exist)">U-151</a> attacked ships outside the port.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">[91]</a></sup> In 1926, Dr. <a href="/w/index.php?title=W.A.R._Goodwin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="W.A.R. Goodwin (page does not exist)">W.A.R. Goodwin</a>, rector of Williamsburg's <a href="/wiki/Bruton_Parish_Church" title="Bruton Parish Church">Bruton Parish Church</a>, began restoration of colonial-era buildings in the historic district with financial backing of <a href="/wiki/John_D._Rockefeller,_Jr." title="John D. Rockefeller, Jr.">John D. Rockefeller, Jr.</a><sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">[92]</a></sup> Though their project, like others in the state, had to contend with the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Great_Depression&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Great Depression (page does not exist)">Great Depression</a> and <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, work continued as <a href="/wiki/Colonial_Williamsburg" title="Colonial Williamsburg">Colonial Williamsburg</a> became a major tourist attraction.<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">[93]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Virginia_Civil_Rights_Memorial_wide.jpg" title="File:Virginia Civil Rights Memorial wide.jpg">File:Virginia Civil Rights Memorial wide.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virginia_Civil_Rights_Memorial&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virginia Civil Rights Memorial (page does not exist)">Virginia Civil Rights Memorial</a> was erected in 2008 to commemorate the protests which led to school desegregation.</div></div></div>
<p>Protests started by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Barbara_Rose_Johns&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Barbara Rose Johns (page does not exist)">Barbara Rose Johns</a> in 1951 in <a href="/wiki/Farmville,_Virginia" title="Farmville, Virginia">Farmville</a> against segregated schools led to the lawsuit <i><a href="/wiki/Davis_v._County_School_Board_of_Prince_Edward_County" title="Davis v. County School Board of Prince Edward County">Davis v. County School Board of Prince Edward County</a></i>. This case, filed by Richmond natives <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spottswood_William_Robinson_III&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Spottswood William Robinson III (page does not exist)">Spottswood Robinson</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Oliver_Hill&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Oliver Hill (page does not exist)">Oliver Hill</a>, was decided in 1954 with <i><a href="/wiki/Brown_v._Board_of_Education" title="Brown v. Board of Education">Brown v. Board of Education</a></i>, which rejected the segregationist doctrine of "<a href="/wiki/Separate_but_equal" title="Separate but equal">separate but equal</a>". But, in 1958, under the policy of "<a href="/wiki/Massive_resistance" title="Massive resistance">massive resistance</a>" led by the influential segregationist Senator <a href="/wiki/Harry_F._Byrd" title="Harry F. Byrd">Harry F. Byrd</a> and his <a href="/wiki/Byrd_Organization" title="Byrd Organization">Byrd Organization</a>, the Commonwealth prohibited <a href="/wiki/Desegregation" title="Desegregation">desegregated</a> local schools from receiving state funding.<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=African-American_Civil_Rights_Movement_(1955%E2%80%931968)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="African-American Civil Rights Movement (1955–1968) (page does not exist)">Civil Rights Movement</a> gained many participants in the 1960s. It achieved the moral force and support to gain passage of national legislation with the <a href="/wiki/Civil_Rights_Act_of_1964" title="Civil Rights Act of 1964">Civil Rights Act of 1964</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Voting_Rights_Act&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Voting Rights Act (page does not exist)">Voting Rights Act</a> of 1965. In 1964 the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Supreme_Court" title="United States Supreme Court" class="mw-redirect">United States Supreme Court</a> ordered <a href="/wiki/Prince_Edward_County,_Virginia" title="Prince Edward County, Virginia">Prince Edward County</a> and others to <a href="/wiki/Racial_integration" title="Racial integration">integrate</a> schools.<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[95]</a></sup> In 1967, the Court also struck down the state's ban on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Interracial_marriage_in_the_United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Interracial marriage in the United States (page does not exist)">interracial marriage</a> with <i><a href="/wiki/Loving_v._Virginia" title="Loving v. Virginia">Loving v. Virginia</a></i>. From 1969 to 1971, state legislators under Governor <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mills_Godwin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mills Godwin (page does not exist)">Mills Godwin</a> rewrote the constitution, after goals such as the repeal of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jim_Crow_laws&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jim Crow laws (page does not exist)">Jim Crow laws</a> had been achieved. In 1989, <a href="/wiki/Douglas_Wilder" title="Douglas Wilder">Douglas Wilder</a> became the first African American elected as governor in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[96]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a> led to the expansion of national defense government programs housed in offices in Northern Virginia near Washington, D.C., and correlative population growth.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">[97]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Central_Intelligence_Agency&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Central Intelligence Agency (page does not exist)">Central Intelligence Agency</a> in <a href="/wiki/Langley,_Virginia" title="Langley, Virginia">Langley</a> was involved in various <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_events_in_the_Cold_War" title="Timeline of events in the Cold War">Cold War events</a>, including as the target of <a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_Soviet_and_Russian_espionage_in_the_United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="History of Soviet and Russian espionage in the United States (page does not exist)">Soviet espionage activities</a>. Also among the federal developments was <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Pentagon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Pentagon (page does not exist)">the Pentagon</a>, built during World War II as the headquarters for the Department of Defense. It was one of the targets of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=September_11_attacks&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="September 11 attacks (page does not exist)">September 11 attacks</a>; 189 people died at the site when a jet passenger plane crashed into the building.<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Cities_and_towns">Cities and towns</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Virginia_population_map.png" title="File:Virginia population map.png">File:Virginia population map.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Virginia metropolitan areas located throughout the state.</div></div></div>
<p>Virginia is divided into 95 <a href="/wiki/List_of_counties_in_Virginia" title="List of counties in Virginia">counties</a> and 38 <a href="/wiki/Independent_city" title="Independent city">independent cities</a>, which both operate the same way since independent cities are considered to be <a href="/wiki/County-equivalent" title="County-equivalent" class="mw-redirect">county-equivalent</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[99]</a></sup> This method of treating cities and counties equally is unique to Virginia, with only three other <a href="/w/index.php?title=Independent_city_(United_States)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Independent city (United States) (page does not exist)">independent cities in the United States</a> outside Virginia.<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">[100]</a></sup> Virginia limits the authority of cities and counties to countermand laws expressly allowed by the <a href="/wiki/Virginia_General_Assembly" title="Virginia General Assembly">Virginia General Assembly</a> under what is known as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dillon%27s_Rule&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dillon's Rule (page does not exist)">Dillon's Rule</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[101]</a></sup> In addition to independent cities, there are also <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_towns_in_Virginia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of towns in Virginia (page does not exist)">incorporated <i>towns</i></a> which operate under their own governments, but are part of a county. Finally there are hundreds of <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_unincorporated_towns_in_Virginia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of unincorporated towns in Virginia (page does not exist)">unincorporated communities</a> within the counties. Virginia does not have any further political subdivisions, such as villages or townships.
</p><p>Virginia has 11 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virginia_census_statistical_areas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virginia census statistical areas (page does not exist)">Metropolitan Statistical Areas</a>; <a href="/wiki/Northern_Virginia" title="Northern Virginia">Northern Virginia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hampton_Roads" title="Hampton Roads">Hampton Roads</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Richmond-Petersburg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Richmond-Petersburg (page does not exist)">Richmond-Petersburg</a> are the three most populous. Richmond is the capital of Virginia, and its metropolitan area has a population of over 1.2&#160;million.<sup id="cite_ref-popnews_102-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-popnews-102">[102]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a>, <a href="/wiki/Virginia_Beach,_Virginia" title="Virginia Beach, Virginia">Virginia Beach</a> is the most populous city in the Commonwealth, with <a href="/wiki/Norfolk,_Virginia" title="Norfolk, Virginia">Norfolk</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chesapeake,_Virginia" title="Chesapeake, Virginia">Chesapeake</a> second and third, respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-c2009_103-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-c2009-103">[103]</a></sup> Norfolk forms the urban core of the Hampton Roads metropolitan area, which has a population over 1.6&#160;million people and is the site of the world's largest naval base, <a href="/wiki/Naval_Station_Norfolk" title="Naval Station Norfolk">Naval Station Norfolk</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-popnews_102-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-popnews-102">[102]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-hr_104-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hr-104">[104]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Suffolk,_Virginia" title="Suffolk, Virginia">Suffolk</a>, which includes a portion of the <a href="/wiki/Great_Dismal_Swamp" title="Great Dismal Swamp">Great Dismal Swamp</a>, is the largest city by area at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">[105]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Fairfax_County,_Virginia" title="Fairfax County, Virginia">Fairfax County</a> is the most populous locality in Virginia, with over one&#160;million residents, although that does not include its county seat Fairfax, which is one of the independent cities.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[106]</a></sup> Fairfax County has a major urban business and shopping center in <a href="/wiki/Tysons_Corner" title="Tysons Corner" class="mw-redirect">Tysons Corner</a>, Virginia's largest office market.<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">[107]</a></sup> Neighboring <a href="/wiki/Loudoun_County,_Virginia" title="Loudoun County, Virginia">Loudoun County</a>, with the county seat at <a href="/wiki/Leesburg,_Virginia" title="Leesburg, Virginia">Leesburg</a>, is both the fastest-growing county in Virginia and has the highest median household income ($114,204) in the country <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ltm_108-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ltm-108">[108]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Arlington_County,_Virginia" title="Arlington County, Virginia">Arlington County</a>, the smallest self-governing county in the United States by land area, is an urban community organized as a county.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[109]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Roanoke,_Virginia" title="Roanoke, Virginia">Roanoke</a> area, with an estimated population of 300,399, is the largest Metropolitan Statistical Area in western Virginia.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[110]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:US_Census_population&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:US Census population (page does not exist)">Template:US Census population</a>
</p>
<table style="float:right;">
<tr>
<td><div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Elizabeth_River_at_NNSY.jpg" title="File:Elizabeth River at NNSY.jpg">File:Elizabeth River at NNSY.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The population of the <a href="/wiki/Hampton_Roads" title="Hampton Roads">Hampton Roads</a> area is over 1.7 million.</div></div></div>
</td></tr></table>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/United_States_Census_Bureau" title="United States Census Bureau">United States Census Bureau</a> estimates that the state population was 8,260,405 on July 1, 2013, a 3.2% increase since the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_United_States_Census&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2010 United States Census (page does not exist)">2010 United States Census</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-PopEstUS_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PopEstUS-1">[1]</a></sup> This includes an increase from net migration of 314,832&#160;people into the Commonwealth since the <a href="/wiki/2000_United_States_Census" title="2000 United States Census">2000 census</a>. <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_the_United_States" title="Immigration to the United States">Immigration</a> from outside the United States resulted in a net increase of 159,627&#160;people, and migration within the country produced a net increase of 155,205&#160;people.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[111]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Center_of_population" title="Center of population">center of population</a> is located in <a href="/wiki/Goochland_County,_Virginia" title="Goochland County, Virginia">Goochland County</a> outside of <a href="/wiki/Richmond,_Virginia" title="Richmond, Virginia">Richmond</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-census_112-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-census-112">[112]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ethnicity">Ethnicity</span></h3>
<p>The state's most populous ethnic group, Non-Hispanic White, has declined from 76% in 1990 to 64.0% in 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[113]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-2011CensusQuickFacts_114-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2011CensusQuickFacts-114">[114]</a></sup> In 2011, non-Hispanic Whites were involved in 50.9% of all the births.<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[115]</a></sup> People of <a href="/w/index.php?title=English_Americans&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="English Americans (page does not exist)">English heritage</a> settled throughout the Commonwealth during the colonial period, and others of British and Irish heritage have since immigrated.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[116]</a></sup> Those who self-identify as having "<a href="/w/index.php?title=American_ethnicity&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="American ethnicity (page does not exist)">American ethnicity</a>" are predominantly of English descent, but have ancestry that has been in North America for so long that they choose to identify simply as American.<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[117]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">[118]</a></sup> Of the English immigrants to Virginia in the 1600s, 75% came as <a href="/wiki/Indentured_servant" title="Indentured servant">indentured servants</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[119]</a></sup> The western mountains have many settlements that were founded by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Scots-Irish_American&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Scots-Irish American (page does not exist)">Scots-Irish immigrants</a> before the <a href="/wiki/American_Revolution" title="American Revolution">American Revolution</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[120]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">[121]</a></sup> There are also sizable numbers of people of German descent in the northwestern mountains and <a href="/wiki/Shenandoah_Valley" title="Shenandoah Valley">Shenandoah Valley</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-dutch_122-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dutch-122">[122]</a></sup> and German ancestry was the most popular response on the 2010 <a href="/wiki/American_Community_Survey" title="American Community Survey">American Community Survey</a>, with 11.7%.<sup id="cite_ref-ancestry_123-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ancestry-123">[123]</a></sup>
</p><p>The largest minority group in Virginia is African American, at 19.7% <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-2011CensusQuickFacts_114-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2011CensusQuickFacts-114">[114]</a></sup> Most African American Virginians have been descendants of enslaved Africans who worked on tobacco, cotton, and <a href="/wiki/Hemp" title="Hemp">hemp</a> plantations. These men, women and children were brought from west-central Africa, primarily from <a href="/wiki/Angola" title="Angola">Angola</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Bight_of_Bonny" title="Bight of Bonny">Bight of Biafra</a>. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Igbo_American&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Igbo American (page does not exist)">Igbo</a> ethnic group of what is now southern <a href="/wiki/Nigeria" title="Nigeria">Nigeria</a> were the single largest African group among slaves in Virginia.<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">[124]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">[125]</a></sup> Though the black population was reduced by the <a href="/wiki/Great_Migration_(African_American)" title="Great Migration (African American)">Great Migration</a>, since 1965 there has been a reverse migration of blacks <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_Great_Migration&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New Great Migration (page does not exist)">returning south</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[126]</a></sup> 2.9% of Virginians also describe themselves as <a href="/wiki/Biracial" title="Biracial" class="mw-redirect">biracial</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-demographics_127-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-demographics-127">[127]</a></sup> Additionally, 0.5% of Virginians are American Indian or Alaska Native, and 0.1% are Native Hawaiian or other Pacific Islander.<sup id="cite_ref-2011CensusQuickFacts_114-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2011CensusQuickFacts-114">[114]</a></sup> Virginia has extended state recognition to eight <a href="/w/index.php?title=Native_American_tribes_in_Virginia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Native American tribes in Virginia (page does not exist)">Native American tribes</a> resident in the state, though all lack federal recognition status. Most Native American groups are located in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tidewater_region_of_Virginia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tidewater region of Virginia (page does not exist)">Tidewater region</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">[128]</a></sup>
</p><p>More recent immigration in the late 20th century and early 21st century has fueled new communities of Hispanics and Asians. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a>, 8.4% of Virginians are <a href="/wiki/Hispanic_and_Latino_Americans" title="Hispanic and Latino Americans">Hispanic</a> or Latino (of any race), and 6.0% are <a href="/w/index.php?title=Asian_people&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Asian people (page does not exist)">Asian</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-2011CensusQuickFacts_114-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2011CensusQuickFacts-114">[114]</a></sup> The state's Hispanic population rose by 92% from 2000 to 2010, with two-thirds of Hispanics living in <a href="/wiki/Northern_Virginia" title="Northern Virginia">Northern Virginia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-demographics_127-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-demographics-127">[127]</a></sup> Hispanic citizens in Virginia have higher median household incomes and educational attainment than the general Virginia population.<sup id="cite_ref-hispanics_129-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hispanics-129">[129]</a></sup> Northern Virginia also has a significant population of <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_American" title="Vietnamese American">Vietnamese Americans</a>, whose major wave of immigration followed the <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_War" title="Vietnam War">Vietnam War</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[130]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Korean_American" title="Korean American">Korean Americans</a>, whose migration has been more recent and was induced in part by the quality school system.<sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131">[131]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Filipino_American" title="Filipino American">Filipino American</a> community has about 45,000 in the <a href="/wiki/Hampton_Roads" title="Hampton Roads">Hampton Roads</a> area, many of whom have ties to the <a href="/wiki/U.S._Navy" title="U.S. Navy" class="mw-redirect">U.S. Navy</a> and armed forces.<sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">[132]</a></sup>
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="margin:1em auto 1em auto">
<tr>
<td>
<table class="wikitable" style="margin:0.5em; border:none;">

<td align="right">10.7%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Hispanic or Latino (of any race)
</td>
<td align="right">8.4%
</td>
<td style="border-right:0;"><div class="key" style="background:green; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; border:2px solid black;">&#160;</div>
</td>
<td style="border-left:0;">Irish
</td>
<td align="right">9.8%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Asian
</td>
<td align="right">6.0%
</td>
<td style="border-right:0;"><div class="key" style="background:#a00; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; border:2px solid black;">&#160;</div>
</td>
<td style="border-left:0;">American
</td>
<td align="right">9.7%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>American Indian and Alaska Native&#160;
</td>
<td align="right">0.5%
</td>
<td style="border-right:0;"><div class="key" style="background:#5a2ca0; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; border:2px solid black;">&#160;</div>
</td>
<td style="border-left:0;">Subsaharan African&#160;
</td>
<td align="right">1.7%
</td></tr></table>
</td></tr></table>
<table class="wikitable sortable collapsible" style="font-size: 90%;">
<caption> <b>Virginia Racial Breakdown of Population</b>
</caption>
<tr>
<th> Racial composition </th>

<th><sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">[134]</a></sup> 2010<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[135]</a></sup>
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=White_American&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="White American (page does not exist)">White</a> </td>
<td> 77.4% </td>
<td> 72.3% </td>
<td> 68.6%
</td></tr>

<td> 19.4%
</td></tr>

<td> 2.6% </td>
<td> 3.7% </td>
<td> 5.5%
</td></tr>

<td> 0.2% </td>
<td> 0.3% </td>
<td> 0.4%
</td></tr>

<td> – </td>
<td> 0.1% </td>
<td> 0.1%
</td></tr>

<td> 0.9% </td>
<td> 2.0% </td>
<td> 3.2%
</td></tr>
<tr>

<td> – </td>
<td> 2.0% </td>
<td> 2.9%
</td></tr></table>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span></h3>
<p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Piedmont_region_of_Virginia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Piedmont region of Virginia (page does not exist)">Piedmont</a> region is known for its dialect's strong influence on <a href="/wiki/Southern_American_English" title="Southern American English">Southern American English</a>.
