While a more homogenized <a href="/wiki/American_English" title="American English">American English</a> is found in urban areas, various accents are also used, including the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tidewater_accent&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tidewater accent (page does not exist)">Tidewater accent</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Old_Virginia_accent&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Old Virginia accent (page does not exist)">Old Virginia accent</a>, and the anachronistic <a href="/wiki/Early_Modern_English" title="Early Modern English">Elizabethan</a> of <a href="/wiki/Tangier_Island" title="Tangier Island" class="mw-redirect">Tangier Island</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[136]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Miller_137-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Miller-137">[137]</a></sup>
</p><p>As of 2010, 85.87% (6,299,127) of Virginia residents age 5 and older spoke <a href="/w/index.php?title=English_language&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="English language (page does not exist)">English</a> at home as a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Primary_language&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Primary language (page does not exist)">primary language</a>, while 6.41% (470,058) spoke <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish</a>, 0.77% (56,518) <a href="/wiki/Korean_language" title="Korean language">Korean</a>, 0.63% (45,881) <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_language" title="Vietnamese language">Vietnamese</a>, 0.57% (42,418) <a href="/wiki/Chinese_language" title="Chinese language">Chinese</a> (which includes <a href="/w/index.php?title=Standard_Mandarin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Standard Mandarin (page does not exist)">Mandarin</a>), and <a href="/wiki/Tagalog_language" title="Tagalog language">Tagalog</a> was spoken as a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Main_language&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Main language (page does not exist)">main language</a> by 0.56% (40,724) of the population over the age of five. In total, 14.13% (1,036,442) of Virginia's population age 5 and older spoke a <a href="/wiki/Mother_language" title="Mother language" class="mw-redirect">mother language</a> other than English.<sup id="cite_ref-MLA_Data_138-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MLA_Data-138">[138]</a></sup> English was passed as the Commonwealth's official language by statutes in 1981 and again in 1996, though the status is not mandated by the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Virginia" title="Constitution of Virginia">Constitution of Virginia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">[139]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3>
<table class="wikitable" style="float:right; margin-left:15px; margin-top:0;">

<tr>
<th style="background:#ccf;" colspan="3">Religion (2008)
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="2" style="border-bottom:0;"><a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christian</a><sup id="cite_ref-aris_140-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-aris-140">[140]</a></sup>
</td>
<td align="right">76%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td rowspan="6" style="border-top:0; border-bottom:0;">
</td>
<td><a href="/w/index.php?title=Baptist&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Baptist (page does not exist)">Baptist</a>
</td>
<td align="right">27%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="/w/index.php?title=Roman_Catholicism_in_the_United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Roman Catholicism in the United States (page does not exist)">Roman Catholic</a>&#160;
</td>
<td align="right">11%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="/wiki/Methodism" title="Methodism">Methodist</a>
</td>
<td align="right">8%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="/wiki/Presbyterianism" title="Presbyterianism">Presbyterian</a>
</td>
<td align="right">3%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lutheranism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lutheranism (page does not exist)">Lutheran</a>
</td>
<td align="right">2%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="/wiki/List_of_Christian_denominations" title="List of Christian denominations">Other Christian</a>
</td>
<td align="right">28%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="3" style="border-top:0;">
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="2"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Buddhism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Buddhism (page does not exist)">Buddhism</a>
</td>
<td align="right">1%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="2"><a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hinduism</a>
</td>
<td align="right">1%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="2"><a href="/wiki/Judaism" title="Judaism">Judaism</a>
</td>
<td align="right">1%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="2"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Islam&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Islam (page does not exist)">Islam</a>
</td>
<td align="right">0.5%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="2"><a href="/wiki/Irreligion" title="Irreligion">Unaffiliated</a>
</td>
<td align="right">18%
</td></tr></table>
<p>Virginia is predominantly Christian and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Protestantism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Protestantism (page does not exist)">Protestant</a>; <a href="/wiki/Baptists" title="Baptists">Baptists</a> are the largest single group with 27% of the population <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-aris_140-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-aris-140">[140]</a></sup> Baptist congregations in Virginia have 763,655 members.<sup id="cite_ref-www.thearda.com_141-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-www.thearda.com-141">[141]</a></sup> Baptist denominational groups in Virginia include the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Baptist_General_Association_of_Virginia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Baptist General Association of Virginia (page does not exist)">Baptist General Association of Virginia</a>, with about 1,400&#160;member churches, which supports both the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Baptist_Convention" title="Southern Baptist Convention">Southern Baptist Convention</a> and the moderate <a href="/wiki/Cooperative_Baptist_Fellowship" title="Cooperative Baptist Fellowship">Cooperative Baptist Fellowship</a>; and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Southern_Baptist_Conservatives_of_Virginia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Southern Baptist Conservatives of Virginia (page does not exist)">Southern Baptist Conservatives of Virginia</a> with more than 500 affiliated churches, which supports the Southern Baptist Convention.<sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">[142]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">[143]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Roman_Catholicism_in_the_United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Roman Catholicism in the United States (page does not exist)">Roman Catholics</a> are the second-largest religious group with 673,853 members.<sup id="cite_ref-www.thearda.com_141-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-www.thearda.com-141">[141]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Diocese_of_Arlington" title="Roman Catholic Diocese of Arlington">Roman Catholic Diocese of Arlington</a> includes most of Northern Virginia's Catholic churches, while the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Diocese_of_Richmond" title="Roman Catholic Diocese of Richmond">Diocese of Richmond</a> covers the rest.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Christchurchalexandria.jpg" title="File:Christchurchalexandria.jpg">File:Christchurchalexandria.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Christ_Church_(Alexandria,_Virginia)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Christ Church (Alexandria, Virginia) (page does not exist)">Christ Church in Alexandria</a> was frequented by <a href="/wiki/George_Washington" title="George Washington">George Washington</a> and <a href="/wiki/Robert_E._Lee" title="Robert E. Lee">Robert E. Lee</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The Virginia Conference is the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Annual_Conference&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Annual Conference (page does not exist)">regional body</a> of the <a href="/wiki/United_Methodist_Church" title="United Methodist Church">United Methodist Church</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virginia_Synod&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virginia Synod (page does not exist)">Virginia Synod</a> is responsible for the congregations of the <a href="/wiki/Evangelical_Lutheran_Church_in_America" title="Evangelical Lutheran Church in America">Lutheran Church</a>. <a href="/wiki/Presbyterianism" title="Presbyterianism">Presbyterians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pentecostalism" title="Pentecostalism">Pentecostals</a>, <a href="/wiki/Congregational_church" title="Congregational church">Congregationalists</a>, and Episcopalians each composed 1–3% of the population <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-aris2001_144-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-aris2001-144">[144]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Episcopal_Diocese_of_Virginia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Episcopal Diocese of Virginia (page does not exist)">Episcopal Diocese of Virginia</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Episcopal_Diocese_of_Southern_Virginia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Episcopal Diocese of Southern Virginia (page does not exist)">Southern Virginia</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Episcopal_Diocese_of_Southwestern_Virginia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Episcopal Diocese of Southwestern Virginia (page does not exist)">Southwestern Virginia</a> support the various <a href="/w/index.php?title=Episcopal_Church_(United_States)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Episcopal Church (United States) (page does not exist)">Episcopal churches</a>.
</p><p>In November 2006, 15 conservative Episcopal churches voted to split from the Diocese of Virginia over the ordination of openly <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gay_bishops&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gay bishops (page does not exist)">gay bishops</a> and clergy in other dioceses of the Episcopal Church; these churches continue to claim affiliation with the larger <a href="/wiki/Anglican_Communion" title="Anglican Communion">Anglican Communion</a> through <a href="/w/index.php?title=Anglican_realignment&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Anglican realignment (page does not exist)">other bodies outside the United States</a>. Though Virginia law allows parishioners to determine their church's affiliation, the diocese claims the secessionist churches' properties. The resulting property law case is a test for Episcopal churches nationwide.<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[145]</a></sup>
</p><p>Among other religions, adherents of <a href="/wiki/The_Church_of_Jesus_Christ_of_Latter-day_Saints" title="The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints">The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints</a> constitute 1% of the population, with 190 <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Church_of_Jesus_Christ_of_Latter-day_Saints_in_Virginia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints in Virginia (page does not exist)">congregations in Virginia</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">[146]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Fairfax_Station,_Virginia" title="Fairfax Station, Virginia">Fairfax Station</a> is the site of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ekoji_Buddhist_Temple&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ekoji Buddhist Temple (page does not exist)">Ekoji Buddhist Temple</a>, of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jodo_Shinshu&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jodo Shinshu (page does not exist)">Jodo Shinshu</a> school, and the Hindu <a href="/wiki/Durga" title="Durga">Durga</a> Temple. While the state's Jewish population is small, organized Jewish sites date to 1789 with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Congregation_Beth_Ahabah&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Congregation Beth Ahabah (page does not exist)">Congregation Beth Ahabah</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">[147]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Muslims" title="Muslims" class="mw-redirect">Muslims</a> are a growing religious group throughout the Commonwealth through immigration.<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">[148]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Megachurch" title="Megachurch">Megachurches</a> in the Commonwealth include <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Road_Baptist_Church" title="Thomas Road Baptist Church">Thomas Road Baptist Church</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Immanuel_Bible_Church&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Immanuel Bible Church (page does not exist)">Immanuel Bible Church</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=McLean_Bible_Church&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="McLean Bible Church (page does not exist)">McLean Bible Church</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">[149]</a></sup> Several Christian universities are also based in the state, including <a href="/wiki/Regent_University" title="Regent University">Regent University</a>, <a href="/wiki/Liberty_University" title="Liberty University">Liberty University</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Lynchburg_College" title="Lynchburg College">Lynchburg College</a>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Pentagon_January_2008.jpg" title="File:The Pentagon January 2008.jpg">File:The Pentagon January 2008.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States_Department_of_Defense&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States Department of Defense (page does not exist)">Department of Defense</a> is headquartered in <a href="/wiki/Arlington_County,_Virginia" title="Arlington County, Virginia">Arlington</a> at <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Pentagon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Pentagon (page does not exist)">The Pentagon</a>, the world's largest office building.<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[150]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:USPTOHQ.jpg" title="File:USPTOHQ.jpg">File:USPTOHQ.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A portion of the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Patent_and_Trademark_Office" title="United States Patent and Trademark Office">Patent and Trademark Office</a> headquarters complex in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Alexandria,_Virginia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alexandria, Virginia (page does not exist)">Alexandria</a>.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Virginia_Beach_waterfront.jpg" title="File:Virginia Beach waterfront.jpg">File:Virginia Beach waterfront.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Ocean tourism is an important sector of <a href="/wiki/Virginia_Beach,_Virginia" title="Virginia Beach, Virginia">Virginia Beach's</a> economy.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Farmers_in_Rockingham_County,_Virginia.jpg" title="File:Farmers in Rockingham County, Virginia.jpg">File:Farmers in Rockingham County, Virginia.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Rockingham_County,_Virginia" title="Rockingham County, Virginia">Rockingham County</a> is Virginia's leading county in agriculture.<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[151]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Virginia is an <a href="/wiki/At-will_employment" title="At-will employment">employment-at-will</a> state;<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">[152]</a></sup> its economy has diverse sources of income, including local and federal government, military, farming and business. Virginia has 4.1&#160;million civilian workers, and one-third of the jobs are in the <a href="/wiki/Service_sector" title="Service sector" class="mw-redirect">service sector</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-energy_153-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-energy-153">[153]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ng_154-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ng-154">[154]</a></sup> The unemployment rate in Virginia is among the <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_US_states_by_unemployment_rate&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of US states by unemployment rate (page does not exist)">lowest in the nation</a>, at 5.2%, as of April 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">[155]</a></sup> The second fastest job growth town in the nation is <a href="/wiki/Leesburg,_Virginia" title="Leesburg, Virginia">Leesburg</a>, as of 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">[156]</a></sup> The Gross Domestic Product of Virginia was $424 billion in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">[157]</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/Bureau_of_Economic_Analysis" title="Bureau of Economic Analysis">Bureau of Economic Analysis</a>, Virginia had the most counties in the top 100 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Highest-income_counties_in_the_United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Highest-income counties in the United States (page does not exist)">wealthiest in the United States</a> based upon median income in 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">[158]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Northern_Virginia" title="Northern Virginia">Northern Virginia</a> is the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Highest-income_counties_in_the_United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Highest-income counties in the United States (page does not exist)">highest-income region</a> in Virginia, having six of the twenty <a href="/w/index.php?title=Highest-income_counties_in_the_United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Highest-income counties in the United States (page does not exist)">highest-income counties</a> in the United States, including the three highest <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">[159]</a></sup> According to CNN Money Magazine the highest-income town in the nation is <a href="/wiki/Great_Falls,_Virginia" title="Great Falls, Virginia">Great Falls</a>, as of 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">[160]</a></sup> According to a 2013 study by Phoenix Marketing International, Virginia had the seventh-largest number of millionaires per capita in the United States, with a ratio of 6.64%.<sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161">[161]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Federal_government">Federal government</span></h3>
<p>Virginia has the highest defense spending of any state per capita, providing the Commonwealth with around 900,000 jobs.<sup id="cite_ref-lovehate_162-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lovehate-162">[162]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-fedspend_163-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fedspend-163">[163]</a></sup> 12% of all <a href="/w/index.php?title=Government_procurement_in_the_United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Government procurement in the United States (page does not exist)">U.S. federal procurement</a> money is spent in Virginia, the second-highest amount after California.<sup id="cite_ref-fedspend_163-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fedspend-163">[163]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-weighdefense_164-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-weighdefense-164">[164]</a></sup> Virginia has one of the highest concentrations of veterans of any state,<sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">[165]</a></sup> and is second to <a href="/wiki/California" title="California">California</a> in total Department of Defense employees.<sup id="cite_ref-weighdefense_164-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-weighdefense-164">[164]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">[166]</a></sup> Many Virginians work for <a href="/wiki/List_of_United_States_federal_agencies" title="List of United States federal agencies">federal agencies</a> in Northern Virginia, which include the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Central_Intelligence_Agency&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Central Intelligence Agency (page does not exist)">Central Intelligence Agency</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States_Department_of_Defense&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States Department of Defense (page does not exist)">Department of Defense</a>, as well as the <a href="/wiki/National_Science_Foundation" title="National Science Foundation">National Science Foundation</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States_Geological_Survey&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States Geological Survey (page does not exist)">United States Geological Survey</a> and the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Patent_and_Trademark_Office" title="United States Patent and Trademark Office">United States Patent and Trademark Office</a>. Many others work for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Government_contractor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Government contractor (page does not exist)">government contractors</a>, including defense and security firms, which hold more than 15,000 federal contracts.<sup id="cite_ref-fedjobs_167-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fedjobs-167">[167]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Hampton_Roads" title="Hampton Roads">Hampton Roads</a> area has the largest concentration of military personnel and assets of any metropolitan area in the world,<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">[168]</a></sup> including the largest naval base in the world, <a href="/wiki/Naval_Station_Norfolk" title="Naval Station Norfolk">Naval Station Norfolk</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-hr_104-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hr-104">[104]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Technology">Technology</span></h3>
<p>Virginia has the highest concentration of technology workers of any state,<sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169">[169]</a></sup> and the fourth-highest number of technology workers after <a href="/wiki/California" title="California">California</a>, <a href="/wiki/Texas" title="Texas">Texas</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New York (page does not exist)">New York</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">[170]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Integrated_circuit" title="Integrated circuit">Computer chips</a> became the state's highest-grossing export in 2006, surpassing its traditional top exports of coal and tobacco combined.<sup id="cite_ref-chips_5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-chips-5">[5]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Northern_Virginia" title="Northern Virginia">Northern Virginia</a>, once considered the state's dairy capital, now hosts software, communication technology, defense contracting companies, particularly in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dulles_Technology_Corridor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dulles Technology Corridor (page does not exist)">Dulles Technology Corridor</a>. Northern Virginia's <a href="/wiki/Data_center" title="Data center">data centers</a> currently carry more than 50% of the nation's internet traffic, and by 2012 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dominion_Virginia_Power&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dominion Virginia Power (page does not exist)">Dominion Power</a> expects that 10% of all its electricity in Northern Virginia will be used by data centers.<sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">[171]</a></sup> As 2013, the state had one of the highest average Internet speeds in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">[172]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Commerce">Commerce</span></h3>
<p>Virginia companies received the fourth-highest amount of venture capital funding in the first half of 2011 after California, <a href="/wiki/Massachusetts" title="Massachusetts">Massachusetts</a>, and New York.<sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">[173]</a></sup> In 2009, <i><a href="/wiki/Forbes_Magazine" title="Forbes Magazine" class="mw-redirect">Forbes Magazine</a></i> named Virginia the best state in the nation for business for the fourth year in a row,<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">[174]</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/CNBC" title="CNBC">CNBC</a> named it the <a href="/w/index.php?title=America%27s_Top_States_For_Business&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="America's Top States For Business (page does not exist)">top state for business</a> in 2007, 2009, and 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">[175]</a></sup> Virginia has 20 <a href="/wiki/Fortune_500" title="Fortune 500">Fortune 500</a> companies, ranking the state eighth nationwide.<sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">[176]</a></sup> Tourism in Virginia supported an estimated 210,000 jobs and generated $21.2 billion in 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">[177]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Arlington_County,_Virginia" title="Arlington County, Virginia">Arlington County</a> is the top tourist destination in the state by domestic spending, followed by <a href="/wiki/Fairfax_County,_Virginia" title="Fairfax County, Virginia">Fairfax County</a>, <a href="/wiki/Loudoun_County,_Virginia" title="Loudoun County, Virginia">Loudoun County</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Virginia_Beach,_Virginia" title="Virginia Beach, Virginia">Virginia Beach</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-fairfaxnarrowly_178-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fairfaxnarrowly-178">[178]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Tysons_Corner" title="Tysons Corner" class="mw-redirect">Tysons Corner</a> is one of the largest business districts in the nation.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Agriculture">Agriculture</span></h3>
<p>Agriculture occupies 32% of the land in Virginia. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a>, about 357,000 Virginian jobs were in agriculture, with over 47,000&#160;farms, averaging <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>, in a total farmland area of 8.1&#160;million acres (12,656&#160;sq&#160;mi; 32,780&#160;km<sup>2</sup>). Though agriculture has declined significantly since 1960 when there were twice as many farms, it remains the largest single industry in Virginia.<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">[179]</a></sup> Tomatoes surpassed soy as the most profitable crop in Virginia in 2006, with peanuts and hay as other agricultural products.<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">[180]</a></sup> Although it is no longer the primary crop, Virginia is still the fifth-largest producer of tobacco nationwide.<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">[181]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Eastern_oyster" title="Eastern oyster">Eastern oyster</a> harvests are an important part of the <a href="/wiki/Chesapeake_Bay" title="Chesapeake Bay">Chesapeake Bay</a> economy, but declining oyster populations from disease, pollution, and overfishing have diminished catches.<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">[182]</a></sup> Wineries and vineyards in the <a href="/wiki/Northern_Neck" title="Northern Neck">Northern Neck</a> and along the <a href="/wiki/Blue_Ridge_Mountains" title="Blue Ridge Mountains">Blue Ridge Mountains</a> also have begun to generate income and attract tourists.<sup id="cite_ref-wine_183-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wine-183">[183]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Taxes">Taxes</span></h3>
<p>Virginia collects personal <a href="/wiki/Income_tax" title="Income tax">income tax</a> in five income brackets, ranging from 3.0% to 5.75%. The state sales and <a href="/wiki/Use_tax" title="Use tax">use tax</a> rate is 4%, while the tax rate on food is 1.5%. There is an additional 1% local tax, for a total of a 5% combined <a href="/wiki/Sales_tax" title="Sales tax">sales tax</a> on most Virginia purchases and 2.5% on most food.<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">[184]</a></sup> Virginia's <a href="/wiki/Property_tax" title="Property tax">property tax</a> is set and collected at the local government level and varies throughout the Commonwealth. Real estate is also taxed at the local level based on 100% of fair market value. Tangible personal property also is taxed at the local level and is based on a percentage or percentages of original cost.<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">[185]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Colonial_Williamsburg_ladies.jpg" title="File:Colonial Williamsburg ladies.jpg">File:Colonial Williamsburg ladies.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Colonial Virginian culture, language, and style are reenacted in <a href="/wiki/Colonial_Williamsburg" title="Colonial Williamsburg">Williamsburg</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Virginia's culture was popularized and spread across America and the <a href="/wiki/Southern_United_States" title="Southern United States">South</a> by figures such as <a href="/wiki/George_Washington" title="George Washington">George Washington</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Jefferson" title="Thomas Jefferson">Thomas Jefferson</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Robert_E._Lee" title="Robert E. Lee">Robert E. Lee</a>. Their homes in Virginia represent the birthplace of America and the South.<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186">[186]</a></sup> Modern Virginia culture has many sources, and is part of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Culture_of_the_Southern_United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Culture of the Southern United States (page does not exist)">culture of the Southern United States</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187">[187]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Smithsonian_Institution" title="Smithsonian Institution">Smithsonian Institution</a> divides Virginia into nine cultural regions.<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">[188]</a></sup>
</p><p>Besides the general <a href="/wiki/Cuisine_of_the_Southern_United_States" title="Cuisine of the Southern United States">cuisine of the Southern United States</a>, Virginia maintains its own particular traditions. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virginia_wine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virginia wine (page does not exist)">Virginia wine</a> is made in many parts of the state.<sup id="cite_ref-wine_183-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wine-183">[183]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Smithfield_ham" title="Smithfield ham">Smithfield ham</a>, sometimes called "Virginia ham", is a type of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Country_ham&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Country ham (page does not exist)">country ham</a> which is <a href="/wiki/Geographical_indication" title="Geographical indication">protected by state law</a>, and can only be produced in the town of <a href="/wiki/Smithfield,_Virginia" title="Smithfield, Virginia">Smithfield</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189">[189]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virginia_furniture&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virginia furniture (page does not exist)">Virginia furniture</a> and architecture are typical of <a href="/wiki/American_colonial_architecture" title="American colonial architecture">American colonial architecture</a>. Thomas Jefferson and many of the state's early leaders favored the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Neoclassical_architecture&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Neoclassical architecture (page does not exist)">Neoclassical architecture</a> style, leading to its use for important state buildings. The <a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania_Dutch" title="Pennsylvania Dutch">Pennsylvania Dutch</a> and their style can also be found in parts of the state.<sup id="cite_ref-dutch_122-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dutch-122">[122]</a></sup>
</p><p>Literature in Virginia often deals with the state's extensive and sometimes troubled past. The works of <a href="/wiki/Pulitzer_Prize" title="Pulitzer Prize">Pulitzer Prize</a> winner <a href="/wiki/Ellen_Glasgow" title="Ellen Glasgow">Ellen Glasgow</a> often dealt with social inequalities and the role of women in her culture.<sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190">[190]</a></sup> Glasgow's peer and close friend <a href="/wiki/James_Branch_Cabell" title="James Branch Cabell">James Branch Cabell</a> wrote extensively about the changing position of gentry in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Reconstruction_era_of_the_United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Reconstruction era of the United States (page does not exist)">Reconstruction era</a>, and challenged its moral code with <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Jurgen,_A_Comedy_of_Justice&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jurgen, A Comedy of Justice (page does not exist)">Jurgen, A Comedy of Justice</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">[191]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/William_Styron" title="William Styron">William Styron</a> approached history in works such as <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Confessions_of_Nat_Turner_(1967)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Confessions of Nat Turner (1967) (page does not exist)">The Confessions of Nat Turner</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Sophie%27s_Choice_(novel)" title="Sophie's Choice (novel)">Sophie's Choice</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">[192]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Tom_Wolfe" title="Tom Wolfe">Tom Wolfe</a> has occasionally dealt with his southern heritage in bestsellers like <i><a href="/wiki/I_Am_Charlotte_Simmons" title="I Am Charlotte Simmons">I Am Charlotte Simmons</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">[193]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mount_Vernon,_Virginia" title="Mount Vernon, Virginia">Mount Vernon</a> native <a href="/w/index.php?title=Matt_Bondurant&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Matt Bondurant (page does not exist)">Matt Bondurant</a> received critical acclaim for his historic novel <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Wettest_County_in_the_World&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Wettest County in the World (page does not exist)">The Wettest County in the World</a></i> about moonshiners in <a href="/wiki/Franklin_County,_Virginia" title="Franklin County, Virginia">Franklin County</a> during <a href="/w/index.php?title=Prohibition_in_the_United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Prohibition in the United States (page does not exist)">prohibition</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">[194]</a></sup> Virginia also names a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Poet_Laureate_of_Virginia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Poet Laureate of Virginia (page does not exist)">state Poet Laureate</a>, currently <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sofia_Starnes&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sofia Starnes (page does not exist)">Sofia Starnes</a> of <a href="/wiki/Williamsburg,_Virginia" title="Williamsburg, Virginia">Williamsburg</a>, who will serve until mid-2014.<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">[195]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Fine_and_performing_arts">Fine and performing arts</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Wolf_Trap_(national_park)_meadow_pavilion.jpg" title="File:Wolf Trap (national park) meadow pavilion.jpg">File:Wolf Trap (national park) meadow pavilion.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The Meadow Pavilion is one of the theaters at <a href="/wiki/Wolf_Trap_National_Park_for_the_Performing_Arts" title="Wolf Trap National Park for the Performing Arts">Wolf Trap National Park for the Performing Arts</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Rich in cultural heritage, Virginia ranks near the bottom of U.S. states in terms of public spending on the arts, at nearly half of the national average.<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">[196]</a></sup> The state government does fund some institutions, including the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virginia_Museum_of_Fine_Arts&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virginia Museum of Fine Arts (page does not exist)">Virginia Museum of Fine Arts</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Science_Museum_of_Virginia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Science Museum of Virginia (page does not exist)">Science Museum of Virginia</a>. Other museums include the popular <a href="/wiki/Steven_F._Udvar-Hazy_Center" title="Steven F. Udvar-Hazy Center">Steven F. Udvar-Hazy Center</a> of the <a href="/wiki/National_Air_and_Space_Museum" title="National Air and Space Museum">National Air and Space Museum</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chrysler_Museum_of_Art&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chrysler Museum of Art (page does not exist)">Chrysler Museum of Art</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">[197]</a></sup> Besides these sites, many open-air museums are located in the Commonwealth, such as <a href="/wiki/Colonial_Williamsburg" title="Colonial Williamsburg">Colonial Williamsburg</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Frontier_Culture_Museum_of_Virginia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frontier Culture Museum of Virginia (page does not exist)">Frontier Culture Museum</a>, and various historic battlefields.<sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198">[198]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virginia_Foundation_for_the_Humanities&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virginia Foundation for the Humanities (page does not exist)">Virginia Foundation for the Humanities</a> works to improve the Commonwealth's civic, cultural, and intellectual life.<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">[199]</a></sup>
</p><p>Theaters and venues in the Commonwealth are found both in the cities and suburbs. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Harrison_Opera_House&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Harrison Opera House (page does not exist)">Harrison Opera House</a>, in <a href="/wiki/Norfolk,_Virginia" title="Norfolk, Virginia">Norfolk</a>, is home of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virginia_Opera&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virginia Opera (page does not exist)">Virginia Opera</a>. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virginia_Symphony_Orchestra&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virginia Symphony Orchestra (page does not exist)">Virginia Symphony Orchestra</a> operates in and around <a href="/wiki/Hampton_Roads" title="Hampton Roads">Hampton Roads</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200">[200]</a></sup>
Resident and touring theater troupes operate from the <a href="/w/index.php?title=American_Shakespeare_Center&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="American Shakespeare Center (page does not exist)">American Shakespeare Center</a> in <a href="/wiki/Staunton,_Virginia" title="Staunton, Virginia">Staunton</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">[201]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Barter_Theatre" title="Barter Theatre">Barter Theatre</a>, designated the State Theatre of Virginia, in <a href="/wiki/Abingdon,_Virginia" title="Abingdon, Virginia">Abingdon</a> won the first ever <a href="/wiki/Regional_Theatre_Tony_Award" title="Regional Theatre Tony Award">Regional Theatre Tony Award</a> in 1948, while the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Signature_Theatre_(Arlington,_Virginia)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Signature Theatre (Arlington, Virginia) (page does not exist)">Signature Theatre</a> in <a href="/wiki/Arlington,_Virginia" title="Arlington, Virginia" class="mw-redirect">Arlington</a> won it in 2009. There's also a Children's Theater of Virginia, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Theatre_IV&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Theatre IV (page does not exist)">Theatre IV</a>, which is the second largest touring troupe nationwide.<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">[202]</a></sup>
</p><p>Virginia has launched many award-winning traditional musical artists and internationally successful popular music acts, as well as Hollywood actors.<sup id="cite_ref-factpack_203-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-factpack-203">[203]</a></sup> Virginia is known for its tradition in the music genres of <a href="/wiki/Old-time_music" title="Old-time music">old-time string</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bluegrass_music" title="Bluegrass music">bluegrass</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Blues" title="Blues">blues</a>, as well as <a href="/wiki/Gospel_(music)" title="Gospel (music)" class="mw-redirect">gospel</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Shout_band&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Shout band (page does not exist)">shout bands</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204">[204]</a></sup> Contemporary Virginia is also known for <a href="/wiki/Folk_rock" title="Folk rock">folk rock</a> artists like <a href="/wiki/Dave_Matthews" title="Dave Matthews">Dave Matthews</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jason_Mraz" title="Jason Mraz">Jason Mraz</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hip_hop&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hip hop (page does not exist)">hip hop</a> stars like <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pharrell&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pharrell (page does not exist)">Pharrell</a> and <a href="/wiki/Missy_Elliott" title="Missy Elliott">Missy Elliott</a>, as well as <a href="/wiki/Thrash_metal" title="Thrash metal">thrash metal</a> groups like <a href="/w/index.php?title=GWAR&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="GWAR (page does not exist)">GWAR</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lamb_of_God_(band)" title="Lamb of God (band)">Lamb of God</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205">[205]</a></sup> Notable performance venues include <a href="/wiki/The_Birchmere" title="The Birchmere">The Birchmere</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Landmark_Theater_(Richmond,_Virginia)" title="Landmark Theater (Richmond, Virginia)">Landmark Theater</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jiffy_Lube_Live&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jiffy Lube Live (page does not exist)">Jiffy Lube Live</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206">[206]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Wolf_Trap_National_Park_for_the_Performing_Arts" title="Wolf Trap National Park for the Performing Arts">Wolf Trap National Park for the Performing Arts</a> is located in <a href="/wiki/Vienna,_Virginia" title="Vienna, Virginia">Vienna</a> and is the only national park intended for use as a performing arts center.<sup id="cite_ref-wolftrap_207-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wolftrap-207">[207]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Festivals">Festivals</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Chincoteague_pony_swim_2007.jpg" title="File:Chincoteague pony swim 2007.jpg">File:Chincoteague pony swim 2007.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The annual <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chincoteague_Pony&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chincoteague Pony (page does not exist)">Chincoteague Pony</a> Swim features over 200 wild ponies swimming across the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Assateague_Channel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Assateague Channel (page does not exist)">Assateague Channel</a> into <a href="/wiki/Chincoteague,_Virginia" title="Chincoteague, Virginia">Chincoteague</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Many counties and localities host <a href="/wiki/County_fair" title="County fair" class="mw-redirect">county fairs</a> and festivals. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virginia_State_Fair&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virginia State Fair (page does not exist)">Virginia State Fair</a> is held at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Meadow_Event_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Meadow Event Park (page does not exist)">Meadow Event Park</a> every September. Also in September is the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Neptune_Festival&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Neptune Festival (page does not exist)">Neptune Festival</a> in <a href="/wiki/Virginia_Beach,_Virginia" title="Virginia Beach, Virginia">Virginia Beach</a>, which celebrates the city, the waterfront, and regional artists. <a href="/wiki/Norfolk,_Virginia#Parks_and_recreation" title="Norfolk, Virginia">Norfolk's Harborfest</a>, in June, features boat racing and <a href="/wiki/Air_show" title="Air show">air shows</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">[208]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Fairfax_County,_Virginia" title="Fairfax County, Virginia">Fairfax County</a> also sponsors <a href="/w/index.php?title=Celebrate_Fairfax!&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Celebrate Fairfax! (page does not exist)">Celebrate Fairfax!</a> with popular and traditional music performances.<sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">[209]</a></sup> The Virginia Lake Festival is held during the third weekend in July in <a href="/wiki/Clarksville,_VA" title="Clarksville, VA" class="mw-redirect">Clarksville</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210">[210]</a></sup> Wolf Trap hosts the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Wolf_Trap_Opera_Company&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wolf Trap Opera Company (page does not exist)">Wolf Trap Opera Company</a>, which produces an opera festival every summer.<sup id="cite_ref-wolftrap_207-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wolftrap-207">[207]</a></sup> Each September, Bay Days celebrates the Chesapeake Bay as well as Hampton's 400 year history since 1610, and Isle of Wight County holds a County Fair on the second week of September as well. Both feature live music performances, and other unique events.
</p><p>On the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Shore_of_Virginia" title="Eastern Shore of Virginia">Eastern Shore</a> island of <a href="/wiki/Chincoteague,_Virginia" title="Chincoteague, Virginia">Chincoteague</a> the annual Pony Swim &amp; Auction of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Feral&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Feral (page does not exist)">feral</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chincoteague_Pony&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chincoteague Pony (page does not exist)">Chincoteague ponies</a> at the end of July is a unique local tradition expanded into a week-long carnival. The <a href="/wiki/Shenandoah_Apple_Blossom_Festival" title="Shenandoah Apple Blossom Festival">Shenandoah Apple Blossom Festival</a> is a six-day festival held annually in <a href="/wiki/Winchester,_Virginia" title="Winchester, Virginia">Winchester</a> that includes parades and <a href="/wiki/Bluegrass_music" title="Bluegrass music">bluegrass</a> concerts. The <a href="/wiki/Old-time_music" title="Old-time music">Old Time</a> Fiddlers' Convention in <a href="/wiki/Galax,_Virginia" title="Galax, Virginia">Galax</a>, begun in 1935, is one of the oldest and largest such events worldwide. Two important film festivals, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virginia_Film_Festival&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virginia Film Festival (page does not exist)">Virginia Film Festival</a> and the <a href="/wiki/VCU_French_Film_Festival" title="VCU French Film Festival">VCU French Film Festival</a>, are held annually in <a href="/wiki/Charlottesville,_Virginia" title="Charlottesville, Virginia">Charlottesville</a> and Richmond, respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">[211]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Media">Media</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:USA_Today_building.jpg" title="File:USA Today building.jpg">File:USA Today building.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><i><a href="/wiki/USA_Today" title="USA Today">USA Today</a></i>, the nation's most circulated newspaper, has its headquarters in McLean.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Hampton_Roads" title="Hampton Roads">Hampton Roads</a> area is the 43rd-largest <a href="/wiki/Media_market" title="Media market">media market</a> in the United States as ranked by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nielsen_Media_Research&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nielsen Media Research (page does not exist)">Nielsen Media Research</a>, while the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Richmond-Petersburg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Richmond-Petersburg (page does not exist)">Richmond-Petersburg</a> area is 57th and <a href="/wiki/Roanoke,_Virginia" title="Roanoke, Virginia">Roanoke</a>-<a href="/wiki/Lynchburg,_Virginia" title="Lynchburg, Virginia">Lynchburg</a> is 66th <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">[212]</a></sup> Northern Virginia is part of the much larger Washington, D.C. media market.
</p><p>There are 36 <a href="/wiki/List_of_television_stations_in_Virginia" title="List of television stations in Virginia">television stations in Virginia</a>, representing each major <a href="/wiki/List_of_United_States_over-the-air_television_networks" title="List of United States over-the-air television networks">U.S. network</a>, part of 42 stations which serve Virginia viewers.<sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213">[213]</a></sup> More than 720 <a href="/wiki/Federal_Communications_Commission" title="Federal Communications Commission">FCC</a>-licensed FM <a href="/w/index.php?title=Radio&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Radio (page does not exist)">radio</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_radio_stations_in_Virginia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of radio stations in Virginia (page does not exist)">stations broadcast in Virginia</a>, with about 300 such AM stations.<sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214">[214]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215">[215]</a></sup> The nationally available <a href="/w/index.php?title=Public_Broadcasting_Service&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Public Broadcasting Service (page does not exist)">Public Broadcasting Service</a> (PBS) is headquartered in <a href="/wiki/Arlington,_Virginia" title="Arlington, Virginia" class="mw-redirect">Arlington</a>. Independent PBS affiliates exist throughout Virginia, and the Arlington PBS member station <a href="/wiki/WETA-TV" title="WETA-TV">WETA-TV</a> produces programs such as the <i><a href="/wiki/PBS_NewsHour" title="PBS NewsHour">PBS NewsHour</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Washington_Week" title="Washington Week">Washington Week</a></i>.
</p><p>The most circulated <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_newspapers_in_Virginia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of newspapers in Virginia (page does not exist)">native newspapers in the Commonwealth</a> are <a href="/wiki/Norfolk,_Virginia" title="Norfolk, Virginia">Norfolk's</a> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Virginian-Pilot&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Virginian-Pilot (page does not exist)">The Virginian-Pilot</a></i> (156,968 daily subscribers), the <i><a href="/wiki/Richmond_Times-Dispatch" title="Richmond Times-Dispatch">Richmond Times-Dispatch</a></i> (118,489), <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Roanoke_Times&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Roanoke Times (page does not exist)">The Roanoke Times</a></i> (75,740), and <a href="/wiki/Newport_News,_Virginia" title="Newport News, Virginia">Newport News'</a> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Daily_Press_(Virginia)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Daily Press (Virginia) (page does not exist)">Daily Press</a></i> (63,366), <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">[216]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Dead_link&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Dead link (page does not exist)">Template:Dead link</a> Several <a href="/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a> papers are based in <a href="/wiki/Northern_Virginia" title="Northern Virginia">Northern Virginia</a>, such as <i><a href="/wiki/The_Washington_Examiner" title="The Washington Examiner">The Washington Examiner</a></i> and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Politico_(newspaper)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Politico (newspaper) (page does not exist)">Politico</a></i>. The paper with the nation's widest circulation, <i><a href="/wiki/USA_Today" title="USA Today">USA Today</a></i>, with 1.83 million daily subscriptions, is headquartered in <a href="/wiki/McLean,_Virginia" title="McLean, Virginia">McLean</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">[217]</a></sup> Besides traditional forms of media, Virginia is the home base for telecommunication companies such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Voxant&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Voxant (page does not exist)">Voxant</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=XO_Communications&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="XO Communications (page does not exist)">XO Communications</a>. In Northern Virginia, <a href="/wiki/The_Washington_Post" title="The Washington Post">The Washington Post</a> is the dominant newspaper, since Northern VA is located in the Washington, DC metropolitan area.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Rotunda-dusk.jpg" title="File:Rotunda-dusk.jpg">File:Rotunda-dusk.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/University_of_Virginia" title="University of Virginia">University of Virginia</a>, a <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Site</a>, was founded by President <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Jefferson" title="Thomas Jefferson">Thomas Jefferson</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">[218]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Virginia's educational system consistently ranks in the top ten states on the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Education" title="United States Department of Education">U.S. Department of Education's</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=National_Assessment_of_Educational_Progress&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="National Assessment of Educational Progress (page does not exist)">National Assessment of Educational Progress</a>, with Virginia students outperforming the average in all subject areas and grade levels tested.<sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">[219]</a></sup> The 2011 <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Education_Week&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Education Week (page does not exist)">Quality Counts</a></i> report ranked Virginia's K–12 education fourth best in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220">[220]</a></sup> All school divisions must adhere to educational standards set forth by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virginia_Department_of_Education&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virginia Department of Education (page does not exist)">Virginia Department of Education</a>, which maintains an assessment and accreditation regime known as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Standards_of_Learning&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Standards of Learning (page does not exist)">Standards of Learning</a> to ensure accountability.<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">[221]</a></sup> In 2010, 85% of high school students graduated on-time after four years.<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">[222]</a></sup> Between 2000 and 2008, school enrollment increased 5%, the number of teachers 21%.<sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223">[223]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Public_school_(government_funded)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Public school (government funded) (page does not exist)">Public</a> <a href="/wiki/K%E2%80%9312_(education)" title="K–12 (education)">K–12 schools</a> in Virginia are generally operated by the counties and cities, and not by the state. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a>, a total of 1,267,063&#160;students were enrolled in 1,873&#160;local and regional schools in the Commonwealth, including three <a href="/w/index.php?title=Charter_school&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Charter school (page does not exist)">charter schools</a>, and an additional 109&#160;alternative and special education centers across 132&#160;<a href="/wiki/List_of_school_divisions_in_Virginia" title="List of school divisions in Virginia">school divisions</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224">[224]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225">[225]</a></sup> Besides the general public schools in Virginia, there are <a href="/w/index.php?title=Governor%27s_Schools_(Virginia)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Governor's Schools (Virginia) (page does not exist)">Governor's Schools</a> and selective <a href="/wiki/Magnet_school" title="Magnet school">magnet schools</a>. The Governor's Schools are a collection of more than 40 regional high schools and summer programs intended for gifted students.<sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">[226]</a></sup> The Virginia Council for Private Education oversees the regulation of 320&#160;state accredited and 130&#160;non-accredited private schools.<sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227">[227]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">[228]</a></sup> An additional 24,682 students receive homeschooling.<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">[229]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a>, there are 176&#160;<a href="/wiki/List_of_colleges_and_universities_in_Virginia" title="List of colleges and universities in Virginia">colleges and universities in Virginia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-nces_230-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nces-230">[230]</a></sup> In the <i>U.S. News &amp; World Report</i> ranking of public colleges, the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Virginia" title="University of Virginia">University of Virginia</a> is second and <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_College_of_William_%26_Mary&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The College of William &amp; Mary (page does not exist)">The College of William &amp; Mary</a> is sixth.<sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231">[231]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232">[232]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Virginia_Commonwealth_University" title="Virginia Commonwealth University">Virginia Commonwealth University</a> is ranked the top public graduate school in fine arts, while <a href="/wiki/James_Madison_University" title="James Madison University">James Madison University</a> has been recognized as the top regional public master's program in <a href="/wiki/Southern_United_States" title="Southern United States">The South</a> since 1993.<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">[233]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">[234]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Virginia_Military_Institute" title="Virginia Military Institute">Virginia Military Institute</a> is the oldest state <a href="/wiki/Military_academy" title="Military academy">military college</a> and a top ranked public <a href="/wiki/Liberal_arts_college" title="Liberal arts college">liberal arts college</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235">[235]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236">[236]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/George_Mason_University" title="George Mason University">George Mason University</a> is the largest university in Virginia with over 32,000&#160;students.<sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237">[237]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Virginia_Tech" title="Virginia Tech">Virginia Tech</a> and <a href="/wiki/Virginia_State_University" title="Virginia State University">Virginia State University</a> are the state's <a href="/wiki/Land-grant_university" title="Land-grant university">land-grant universities</a>. Virginia also operates 23 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virginia_Community_College_System&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virginia Community College System (page does not exist)">community colleges</a> on 40 campuses serving over 260,000&#160;students.<sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238">[238]</a></sup> There are 129 private institutions, including <a href="/wiki/Washington_and_Lee_University" title="Washington and Lee University">Washington and Lee University</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Randolph_College&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Randolph College (page does not exist)">Randolph College</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hampden%E2%80%93Sydney_College" title="Hampden–Sydney College">Hampden–Sydney College</a>, <a href="/wiki/Emory_%26_Henry_College" title="Emory &amp; Henry College" class="mw-redirect">Emory &amp; Henry College</a>, <a href="/wiki/Roanoke_College" title="Roanoke College">Roanoke College</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Richmond" title="University of Richmond">University of Richmond</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Randolph-Macon_College&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Randolph-Macon College (page does not exist)">Randolph-Macon College</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-nces_230-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nces-230">[230]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:A.D._Williams_Clinic_and_West_Hospital.jpg" title="File:A.D. Williams Clinic and West Hospital.jpg">File:A.D. Williams Clinic and West Hospital.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The A.D. Williams Clinic and West Hospital at <a href="/w/index.php?title=VCU_Medical_Center&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="VCU Medical Center (page does not exist)">VCU Medical Center</a> in Richmond</div></div></div>
<p>Virginia has a mixed health record, and is ranked as the 20th overall healthiest state according to the 2011 United Health Foundation's Health Rankings.<sup id="cite_ref-ahr_239-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ahr-239">[239]</a></sup> Virginia also ranks 21st among the states in the rate of premature deaths, 7,100 per 100,000. In 2008, Virginia reached its lowest ever rate of <a href="/wiki/Infant_mortality" title="Infant mortality">infant mortality</a>, at 6.7 deaths per&#160;1,000.<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">[240]</a></sup> There are however racial and social health disparities, in 2010 African Americans experienced 28% more premature deaths than whites, while 13% of Virginians lack any <a href="/wiki/Health_insurance" title="Health insurance">health insurance</a>. According to the <a href="/wiki/Centers_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention" title="Centers for Disease Control and Prevention">Centers for Disease Control and Prevention</a>'s 2009 survey, 26% of Virginians are obese and another 35% are overweight. 78% of residents claim to have exercised at least once in the past three months.<sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">[241]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242">[242]</a></sup> About 30% of Virginia's 10- to 17-year-olds are overweight or obese.<sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243">[243]</a></sup> Virginia banned smoking in bars and restaurants in January 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244">[244]</a></sup> 19% of Virginians smoke tobacco.<sup id="cite_ref-ahr_239-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ahr-239">[239]</a></sup> Residents of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virginia%27s_8th_congressional_district&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virginia's 8th congressional district (page does not exist)">Virginia's 8th congressional district</a> share the longest average <a href="/wiki/Life_expectancy" title="Life expectancy">life expectancy</a> rate in the nation, over 83 years.<sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245">[245]</a></sup>
</p><p>There are 89&#160;<a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_hospitals_in_Virginia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of hospitals in Virginia (page does not exist)">hospitals in Virginia</a> listed with the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Health_and_Human_Services" title="United States Department of Health and Human Services">United States Department of Health and Human Services</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246">[246]</a></sup> Notable examples include <a href="/w/index.php?title=Inova_Fairfax_Hospital&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Inova Fairfax Hospital (page does not exist)">Inova Fairfax Hospital</a>, the largest hospital in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Washington_Metropolitan_Area&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Washington Metropolitan Area (page does not exist)">Washington Metropolitan Area</a>, and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=VCU_Medical_Center&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="VCU Medical Center (page does not exist)">VCU Medical Center</a>, located on the medical campus of <a href="/wiki/Virginia_Commonwealth_University" title="Virginia Commonwealth University">Virginia Commonwealth University</a>. The University of Virginia Medical Center, part of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=University_of_Virginia_Health_System&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="University of Virginia Health System (page does not exist)">University of Virginia Health System</a>, is highly ranked in <a href="/wiki/Endocrinology" title="Endocrinology">endocrinology</a> according to <i><a href="/wiki/U.S.News_%26_World_Report" title="U.S.News &amp; World Report" class="mw-redirect">U.S.News &amp; World Report</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247">[247]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sentara_Norfolk_General_Hospital&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sentara Norfolk General Hospital (page does not exist)">Sentara Norfolk General Hospital</a>, part of the <a href="/wiki/Hampton_Roads" title="Hampton Roads">Hampton Roads</a> based <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sentara_Health_System&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sentara Health System (page does not exist)">Sentara Health System</a> and a teaching institution of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Eastern_Virginia_Medical_School&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Eastern Virginia Medical School (page does not exist)">Eastern Virginia Medical School</a>, was the site of the first successful <a href="/wiki/In-vitro_fertilization" title="In-vitro fertilization" class="mw-redirect">in-vitro fertilization</a> birth.<sup id="cite_ref-248" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-248">[248]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249">[249]</a></sup> Virginia has a ratio of 127 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Primary_care_physician&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Primary care physician (page does not exist)">primary care physicians</a> per 10,000 residents, which is the 16th highest nationally.<sup id="cite_ref-ahr_239-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ahr-239">[239]</a></sup> Virginia was one of five states to receive a perfect score in disaster preparedness according to a 2008 report by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Trust_for_America%27s_Health&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Trust for America's Health (page does not exist)">Trust for America's Health</a>, based on criteria such as detecting pathogens and distributing vaccines and medical supplies.<sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250">[250]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Transportation">Transportation</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Virginia_Railway_Express_train.jpg" title="File:Virginia Railway Express train.jpg">File:Virginia Railway Express train.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Virginia_Railway_Express" title="Virginia Railway Express">Virginia Railway Express</a> runs commuter lines in Northern Virginia.</div></div></div>
<p>Because of the 1932 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Byrd_Road_Act&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Byrd Road Act (page does not exist)">Byrd Road Act</a>, the state government controls most of Virginia's roads, instead of a local county authority as is usual in other states.<sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251">[251]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Virginia_Department_of_Transportation" title="Virginia Department of Transportation">Virginia Department of Transportation</a> owns and operates <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of the total <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of roads in the state, making it the third largest state highway system in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-vdot_252-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vdot-252">[252]</a></sup> Although the Washington Metropolitan Area, which includes <a href="/wiki/Northern_Virginia" title="Northern Virginia">Northern Virginia</a>, has the second worst traffic in the nation, Virginia as a whole has the 21st-lowest congestion and the average commute time is 26.9&#160;minutes.<sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253">[253]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">[254]</a></sup>
</p><p>Virginia has <a href="/wiki/Amtrak" title="Amtrak">Amtrak</a> passenger rail service along several corridors, and <a href="/wiki/Virginia_Railway_Express" title="Virginia Railway Express">Virginia Railway Express</a> (VRE) maintains two commuter lines into Washington, D.C. from <a href="/wiki/Fredericksburg,_Virginia" title="Fredericksburg, Virginia">Fredericksburg</a> and <a href="/wiki/Manassas,_Virginia" title="Manassas, Virginia">Manassas</a>. VRE is one of the nation's fastest growing commuter rail services, handling nearly 20,000 passengers a day.<sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255">[255]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Washington_Metro" title="Washington Metro">Washington Metro</a> rapid transit system serves Northern Virginia as far west as communities along I-66 in Fairfax County, with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Silver_Line_(Washington_Metro)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Silver Line (Washington Metro) (page does not exist)">expansion plans</a> to reach <a href="/wiki/Tysons_Corner" title="Tysons Corner" class="mw-redirect">Tysons Corner</a> by 2013, and <a href="/wiki/Loudoun_County,_Virginia" title="Loudoun County, Virginia">Loudoun County</a> by 2017.<sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256">[256]</a></sup> Major freight railroads in Virginia include <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norfolk_Southern&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Norfolk Southern (page does not exist)">Norfolk Southern</a> and <a href="/wiki/CSX_Transportation" title="CSX Transportation">CSX Transportation</a>. Commuter buses include the <a href="/wiki/Fairfax_Connector" title="Fairfax Connector">Fairfax Connector</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Shenandoah_Valley_Commuter_Bus&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Shenandoah Valley Commuter Bus (page does not exist)">Shenandoah Valley Commuter Bus</a>. The Virginia Department of Transportation operates several free ferries throughout Virginia, the most notable being the Jamestown-Scotland ferry which crosses the James River in <a href="/wiki/Surry_County,_Virginia" title="Surry County, Virginia">Surry County</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-257" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-257">[257]</a></sup>
</p><p>Virginia has five major airports: <a href="/wiki/Washington_Dulles_International_Airport" title="Washington Dulles International Airport">Washington Dulles International</a> handling over 23 million passengers a year, and <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan_Washington_National_Airport" title="Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport">Reagan Washington National</a> which both serve the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Washington_metropolitan_area&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Washington metropolitan area (page does not exist)">Washington metropolitan area</a> and most of Northern Virginia, <a href="/wiki/Norfolk_International_Airport" title="Norfolk International Airport">Norfolk International</a> serving the Hampton Roads area, <a href="/wiki/Richmond_International_Airport" title="Richmond International Airport">Richmond International</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Newport_News/Williamsburg_International_Airport" title="Newport News/Williamsburg International Airport">Newport News/Williamsburg International Airport</a>. Several other airports offer limited commercial passenger service, and sixty-six public airports serve the state's aviation needs.<sup id="cite_ref-258" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-258">[258]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virginia_Port_Authority&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virginia Port Authority (page does not exist)">Virginia Port Authority</a>'s main seaports are those in <a href="/wiki/Hampton_Roads" title="Hampton Roads">Hampton Roads</a>, which carried <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of bulk cargo in 2007, the sixth most of United States ports.<sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259">[259]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Shore_of_Virginia" title="Eastern Shore of Virginia">Eastern Shore of Virginia</a> is the site of <a href="/wiki/Wallops_Flight_Facility" title="Wallops Flight Facility">Wallops Flight Facility</a>, a rocket testing center owned by <a href="/w/index.php?title=NASA&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="NASA (page does not exist)">NASA</a>, and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mid-Atlantic_Regional_Spaceport&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mid-Atlantic Regional Spaceport (page does not exist)">Mid-Atlantic Regional Spaceport</a>, a commercial spaceport.<sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260">[260]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-261" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-261">[261]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Space_tourism" title="Space tourism">Space tourism</a> is also offered through <a href="/wiki/Vienna,_Virginia" title="Vienna, Virginia">Vienna</a>-based <a href="/wiki/Space_Adventures" title="Space Adventures">Space Adventures</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-262" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-262">[262]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Law_and_government">Law and government</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
