<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Va_State_Capitol.JPG" title="File:Va State Capitol.JPG">File:Va State Capitol.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Virginia_State_Capitol" title="Virginia State Capitol">Virginia State Capitol</a>, designed by <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Jefferson" title="Thomas Jefferson">Thomas Jefferson</a> and begun by Governor <a href="/wiki/Patrick_Henry" title="Patrick Henry">Patrick Henry</a> in 1785, is home to the <a href="/wiki/Virginia_General_Assembly" title="Virginia General Assembly">Virginia General Assembly</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>In colonial Virginia, free men elected the lower house of the legislature, called the <a href="/w/index.php?title=House_of_Burgesses&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="House of Burgesses (page does not exist)">House of Burgesses</a>, which together with the Governor's Council, made the "General Assembly". Founded in 1619, the <a href="/wiki/Virginia_General_Assembly" title="Virginia General Assembly">Virginia General Assembly</a> is still in existence as the oldest legislature in the Western Hemisphere.<sup id="cite_ref-burgesses_263-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-burgesses-263">[263]</a></sup> The modern government is ranked by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pew_Research_Center&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pew Research Center (page does not exist)">Pew Center on the States</a> with an A− in terms of its efficiency, effectiveness, and infrastructure. This is the second time Virginia received the highest grade in the nation, which it shares with two others.<sup id="cite_ref-pew_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pew-4">[4]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since 1971, the government has functioned under the seventh <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Virginia" title="Constitution of Virginia">Constitution of Virginia</a>, which provides for a strong legislature and a unified judicial system. Similar to the <a href="/wiki/Federal_government_of_the_United_States" title="Federal government of the United States">federal structure</a>, the government is divided in <a href="/wiki/Separation_of_powers" title="Separation of powers">three branches</a>: legislative, executive, and judicial. The legislature is the <a href="/wiki/Virginia_General_Assembly" title="Virginia General Assembly">General Assembly</a>, a bicameral body whose 100-member <a href="/wiki/Virginia_House_of_Delegates" title="Virginia House of Delegates">House of Delegates</a> and 40-member <a href="/wiki/Senate_of_Virginia" title="Senate of Virginia">Senate</a> write the laws for the Commonwealth. The Assembly is stronger than the executive, as it selects judges and justices. The Governor and <a href="/wiki/Lieutenant_Governor_of_Virginia" title="Lieutenant Governor of Virginia">Lieutenant Governor</a> are elected every four years in separate elections. Incumbent <a href="/wiki/List_of_Virginia_Governors" title="List of Virginia Governors" class="mw-redirect">governors</a> cannot run for re-election, however the Lieutenant Governor and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Attorney_General_of_Virginia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Attorney General of Virginia (page does not exist)">Attorney General</a> can, and governors may serve non-consecutive terms.<sup id="cite_ref-constitution_264-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-constitution-264">[264]</a></sup> The judicial system, the oldest in America, consists of a hierarchy from the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Virginia" title="Supreme Court of Virginia">Supreme Court of Virginia</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Court_of_Appeals_of_Virginia" title="Court of Appeals of Virginia">Court of Appeals of Virginia</a> to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virginia_Circuit_Court&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virginia Circuit Court (page does not exist)">Circuit Courts</a>, the trial courts of general jurisdiction, and the lower <a href="/wiki/Virginia_General_District_Court" title="Virginia General District Court">General District Courts</a> and <a href="/wiki/Virginia_Juvenile_and_Domestic_Relations_District_Court" title="Virginia Juvenile and Domestic Relations District Court">Juvenile and Domestic Relations District Courts</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265">[265]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Code_of_Virginia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Code of Virginia (page does not exist)">Code of Virginia</a> is the statutory law, and consists of the codified legislation of the General Assembly. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virginia_State_Police&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virginia State Police (page does not exist)">Virginia State Police</a> is the largest <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_law_enforcement_agencies_in_Virginia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of law enforcement agencies in Virginia (page does not exist)">law enforcement agency in Virginia</a>. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virginia_Capitol_Police&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virginia Capitol Police (page does not exist)">Virginia Capitol Police</a> is the oldest police department in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266">[266]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virginia_National_Guard&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virginia National Guard (page does not exist)">Virginia National Guard</a> consists of 7,500&#160;soldiers in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virginia_Army_National_Guard&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virginia Army National Guard (page does not exist)">Virginia Army National Guard</a> and 1,200&#160;airmen in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virginia_Air_National_Guard&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virginia Air National Guard (page does not exist)">Virginia Air National Guard</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-267" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-267">[267]</a></sup> Since the resumption of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Capital_punishment_in_Virginia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Capital punishment in Virginia (page does not exist)">capital punishment in Virginia</a> in 1982, <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_individuals_executed_in_Virginia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of individuals executed in Virginia (page does not exist)">107 people have been executed</a>, the second highest number in the nation.<sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268">[268]</a></sup> The "total crime risk" is 28% lower than the national average.<sup id="cite_ref-quick_269-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-quick-269">[269]</a></sup> Since Virginia ended prisoner parole in 1995, the rate of <a href="/wiki/Recidivism" title="Recidivism">recidivism</a> has fallen to 28.3%, among the lowest nationwide.<sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270">[270]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">Politics</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="float:right; margin:2em; font-size:90%;">
<caption> <b>Presidential elections results</b><sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271">[271]</a></sup>
</caption>
<tr style="background:lightgrey;">
<th>Year
</th>
<th><a href="/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)" title="Republican Party (United States)">Republicans</a>
</th>
<th><a href="/w/index.php?title=Democratic_Party_(United_States)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Democratic Party (United States) (page does not exist)">Democrats</a>
</th></tr>

</td>

</td>
<td style="text-align:center; background:#f0f0ff;">40.59% <i>1,038,650</i>
</td></tr>
<tr>

</td>
<td style="text-align:center; background:#fff3f3;"><b>59.74%</b> <i>1,309,162</i>
</td>
<td style="text-align:center; background:#f0f0ff;">39.23% <i>859,799</i>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1984" title="United States presidential election, 1984">1984</a>
</td>
<td style="text-align:center; background:#fff3f3;"><b>62.29%</b> <i>1,337,078</i>
</td>
<td style="text-align:center; background:#f0f0ff;">37.09% <i>796,250</i>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1980" title="United States presidential election, 1980">1980</a>
</td>
<td style="text-align:center; background:#fff3f3;"><b>53.03%</b> <i>989,609</i>
</td>
<td style="text-align:center; background:#f0f0ff;">40.31% <i>752,174</i>
</td></tr>
</table>
<p>Over the 20th century, Virginia shifted from a largely rural, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Politics_of_the_Southern_United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Politics of the Southern United States (page does not exist)">politically Southern</a> and conservative state to a more urbanized, pluralistic, and politically moderate environment. Up until the 1970s, Virginia was a racially divided <a href="/wiki/Single-party_state" title="Single-party state">single-party state</a> dominated by the <a href="/wiki/Byrd_Organization" title="Byrd Organization">Byrd Organization</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-272" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-272">[272]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_slavery_in_Virginia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="History of slavery in Virginia (page does not exist)">legacy of slavery in the state</a> effectively <a href="/wiki/Disfranchisement" title="Disfranchisement">disfranchised</a> African Americans until after passage of civil rights legislation in the mid-1960s.<sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273">[273]</a></sup> Enfranchisement and immigration of other groups, especially Hispanics, have placed growing importance on minority voting,<sup id="cite_ref-274" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-274">[274]</a></sup> while voters that identify as "white working-class" declined by three percent between 2008 and 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-obama12_275-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-obama12-275">[275]</a></sup> Regional differences play a large part in Virginia politics.<sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276">[276]</a></sup> Rural southern and western areas moved to support the <a href="/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)" title="Republican Party (United States)">Republican Party</a> in response to its "<a href="/wiki/Southern_strategy" title="Southern strategy">southern strategy</a>", while urban and growing suburban areas, including much of <a href="/wiki/Northern_Virginia" title="Northern Virginia">Northern Virginia</a>, form the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Democratic_Party_(United_States)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Democratic Party (United States) (page does not exist)">Democratic Party</a> <a href="/wiki/Base_(politics)" title="Base (politics)">base</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277">[277]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-278" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-278">[278]</a></sup> Democratic support also persists in union-influenced parts of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Southwest_Virginia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Southwest Virginia (page does not exist)">Southwest Virginia</a>, college towns such as <a href="/wiki/Charlottesville,_Virginia" title="Charlottesville, Virginia">Charlottesville</a> and <a href="/wiki/Blacksburg,_Virginia" title="Blacksburg, Virginia">Blacksburg</a>, and the southeastern <a href="/wiki/Black_Belt_Region" title="Black Belt Region" class="mw-redirect">Black Belt Region</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279">[279]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Political_party_strength_in_Virginia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Political party strength in Virginia (page does not exist)">Political party strength in Virginia</a> has likewise been in flux. In the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virginia_state_elections,_2007&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virginia state elections, 2007 (page does not exist)">2007 state elections</a>, Democrats regained control of the <a href="/wiki/Senate_of_Virginia" title="Senate of Virginia">State Senate</a>, and narrowed the Republican majority in the <a href="/wiki/Virginia_House_of_Delegates" title="Virginia House of Delegates">House of Delegates</a> to eight seats.<sup id="cite_ref-280" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-280">[280]</a></sup> Yet <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virginia_elections,_2009&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virginia elections, 2009 (page does not exist)">elections in 2009</a> resulted in the election of Republican <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bob_McDonnell&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bob McDonnell (page does not exist)">Bob McDonnell</a> as <a href="/wiki/Governor_of_Virginia" title="Governor of Virginia">Governor</a> by a seventeen point margin, the election of a Republican <a href="/wiki/Lieutenant_Governor_of_Virginia" title="Lieutenant Governor of Virginia">Lieutenant Governor</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Attorney_General_of_Virginia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Attorney General of Virginia (page does not exist)">Attorney General</a>, as well as Republican gains of six seats in the House of Delegates.<sup id="cite_ref-281" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-281">[281]</a></sup> In 2011, the Republican caucus took over two-thirds (68–32) of the seats in the House of Delegates, and a majority of the Senate based on the Lieutenant Governor <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bill_Bolling&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bill Bolling (page does not exist)">Bill Bolling</a> as the tie-breaker.<sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282">[282]</a></sup> Following the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virginia_elections,_2013&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virginia elections, 2013 (page does not exist)">2013 elections</a>, Democrat <a href="/w/index.php?title=Terry_McAuliffe&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Terry McAuliffe (page does not exist)">Terry McAuliffe</a> was elected Governor by two and half percentage points, while Democrat <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ralph_Northam&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ralph Northam (page does not exist)">Ralph Northam</a> was elected Lieutenant Governor by almost double digits.<sup id="cite_ref-283" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-283">[283]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-284" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-284">[284]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-elections.huffingtonpost.com_285-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-elections.huffingtonpost.com-285">[285]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286">[286]</a></sup> Republicans, however, maintained their super-majority (67–33) in the House of Delegates.<sup id="cite_ref-elections.huffingtonpost.com_285-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-elections.huffingtonpost.com-285">[285]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287">[287]</a></sup> State election seasons traditionally start with the annual <a href="/w/index.php?title=Shad_Planking&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Shad Planking (page does not exist)">Shad Planking</a> event in <a href="/wiki/Wakefield,_Virginia" title="Wakefield, Virginia">Wakefield</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288">[288]</a></sup>
</p><p>In federal elections since 2006, both parties have seen successes. Republican Senator <a href="/w/index.php?title=George_Allen_(U.S._politician)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="George Allen (U.S. politician) (page does not exist)">George Allen</a> lost close races in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virginia_United_States_Senate_election,_2006&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virginia United States Senate election, 2006 (page does not exist)">2006</a>, to Democratic newcomer <a href="/wiki/Jim_Webb" title="Jim Webb">Jim Webb</a>, and again in <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States_Senate_election_in_Virginia,_2012&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States Senate election in Virginia, 2012 (page does not exist)">2012</a>, to Webb's replacement, former Governor <a href="/wiki/Tim_Kaine" title="Tim Kaine">Tim Kaine</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-289" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-289">[289]</a></sup> In <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States_Senate_election_in_Virginia,_2008&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States Senate election in Virginia, 2008 (page does not exist)">2008</a>, the Democrats took both U.S. Senate seats when former Governor <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mark_Warner&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mark Warner (page does not exist)">Mark Warner</a> was elected to replace retiring Republican <a href="/wiki/John_Warner" title="John Warner">John Warner</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290">[290]</a></sup> Virginia, which has 13 electoral votes, was won by Democrat <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">Barack Obama</a> in <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_2008" title="United States presidential election, 2008">2008</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States_presidential_election,_2012&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States presidential election, 2012 (page does not exist)">2012</a>, after being won by Republican candidates in the previous ten <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States_presidential_election&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States presidential election (page does not exist)">presidential elections</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-obama12_275-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-obama12-275">[275]</a></sup> In the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virginia_elections,_2010&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virginia elections, 2010 (page does not exist)">2010 elections</a>, Republicans picked up three House seats from Democrats. Of the state's <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_United_States_Representatives_from_Virginia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of United States Representatives from Virginia (page does not exist)">11 seats</a> in the <a href="/wiki/U.S._House_of_Representatives" title="U.S. House of Representatives" class="mw-redirect">U.S. House of Representatives</a>, Republicans hold eight and Democrats hold three. Virginia is considered a "<a href="/wiki/Swing_state" title="Swing state">swing state</a>" in future presidential elections.<sup id="cite_ref-purple_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-purple-2">[2]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Glennon_Hands_off_to_Ore_2007_ECU_crop.jpg" title="File:Glennon Hands off to Ore 2007 ECU crop.jpg">File:Glennon Hands off to Ore 2007 ECU crop.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virginia_Tech_Hokies_football&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virginia Tech Hokies football (page does not exist)">Virginia Tech Hokies football</a> team has the second longest <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_Virginia_Tech_Hokies_bowl_games&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of Virginia Tech Hokies bowl games (page does not exist)">bowl game streak</a> in the nation.<sup id="cite_ref-291" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-291">[291]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Virginia is the most populous U.S. state without a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Major_professional_sports_leagues_in_the_United_States_and_Canada&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Major professional sports leagues in the United States and Canada (page does not exist)">major professional sports league</a> franchise.<sup id="cite_ref-292" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-292">[292]</a></sup> The reasons for this include the lack of any dominant city or market within the state, the proximity of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sports_in_Washington,_D.C.&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sports in Washington, D.C. (page does not exist)">teams in Washington, D.C.</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sports_in_North_Carolina&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sports in North Carolina (page does not exist)">North Carolina</a>, and a reluctance to publicly finance stadiums.<sup id="cite_ref-293" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-293">[293]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294">[294]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virginia_Destroyers&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virginia Destroyers (page does not exist)">Virginia Destroyers</a> are based in <a href="/wiki/Virginia_Beach,_Virginia" title="Virginia Beach, Virginia">Virginia Beach</a>, and were the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_UFL_season&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2011 UFL season (page does not exist)">2011 champions</a> of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_Football_League_(2009)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United Football League (2009) (page does not exist)">United Football League</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295">[295]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Norfolk,_Virginia" title="Norfolk, Virginia">Norfolk</a> is host to the two highest-level minor league teams in the state: The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Triple-A_(baseball)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Triple-A (baseball) (page does not exist)">AAA</a> <a href="/wiki/Norfolk_Tides" title="Norfolk Tides">Norfolk Tides</a> and the <a href="/wiki/American_Hockey_League" title="American Hockey League">AHL's</a> <a href="/wiki/Norfolk_Admirals" title="Norfolk Admirals">Norfolk Admirals</a>, winners of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2012_Calder_Cup&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2012 Calder Cup (page does not exist)">2012 Calder Cup</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-296" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-296">[296]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Giants" title="San Francisco Giants">San Francisco Giants</a>' <a href="/w/index.php?title=Double-A_(baseball)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Double-A (baseball) (page does not exist)">AA team</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Richmond_Flying_Squirrels&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Richmond Flying Squirrels (page does not exist)">Richmond Flying Squirrels</a>, began play at <a href="/wiki/The_Diamond_(Richmond,_Virginia)" title="The Diamond (Richmond, Virginia)">The Diamond</a> in 2010, replacing the AAA <a href="/wiki/Richmond_Braves" title="Richmond Braves">Richmond Braves</a>, who relocated after 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-297" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-297">[297]</a></sup> Additionally, the <a href="/wiki/Washington_Nationals" title="Washington Nationals">Washington Nationals</a>, <a href="/wiki/Boston_Red_Sox" title="Boston Red Sox">Boston Red Sox</a>, <a href="/wiki/Seattle_Mariners" title="Seattle Mariners">Seattle Mariners</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chicago_White_Sox" title="Chicago White Sox">Chicago White Sox</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Atlanta_Braves" title="Atlanta Braves">Atlanta Braves</a> also have Single-A and Rookie-level <a href="/wiki/Farm_team" title="Farm team">farm teams</a> in Virginia.<sup id="cite_ref-298" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-298">[298]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Washington_Redskins" title="Washington Redskins">Washington Redskins</a> have Redskins Park, their headquarters, in <a href="/wiki/Ashburn,_Virginia" title="Ashburn, Virginia">Ashburn</a> and their training facility is in Richmond,<sup id="cite_ref-299" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-299">[299]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Washington_Capitals" title="Washington Capitals">Washington Capitals</a> train at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kettler_Capitals_Iceplex&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kettler Capitals Iceplex (page does not exist)">Kettler Capitals Iceplex</a> in <a href="/wiki/Ballston,_Arlington,_Virginia" title="Ballston, Arlington, Virginia">Ballston</a>. Virginia has many professional caliber golf courses including the <a href="/wiki/Greg_Norman" title="Greg Norman">Greg Norman</a> course at Lansdowne Resort and Kingsmill Resort, home of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Michelob_ULTRA_Open_at_Kingsmill&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Michelob ULTRA Open at Kingsmill (page does not exist)">Michelob ULTRA Open</a>. <a href="/wiki/NASCAR" title="NASCAR">NASCAR</a> currently schedules <a href="/wiki/Sprint_Cup_Series" title="Sprint Cup Series">Sprint Cup</a> races on two tracks in Virginia: <a href="/wiki/Martinsville_Speedway" title="Martinsville Speedway">Martinsville Speedway</a> and <a href="/wiki/Richmond_International_Raceway" title="Richmond International Raceway">Richmond International Raceway</a>. Current Virginia drivers in the series include <a href="/wiki/Jeff_Burton" title="Jeff Burton">Jeff Burton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Denny_Hamlin" title="Denny Hamlin">Denny Hamlin</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Elliott_Sadler" title="Elliott Sadler">Elliott Sadler</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-300" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-300">[300]</a></sup>
</p><p>Virginia does not allow state appropriated funds to be used for either operational or capital expenses for intercollegiate athletics.<sup id="cite_ref-301" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-301">[301]</a></sup> Despite this, both the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virginia_Cavaliers&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virginia Cavaliers (page does not exist)">Virginia Cavaliers</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virginia_Tech_Hokies&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virginia Tech Hokies (page does not exist)">Virginia Tech Hokies</a> have been able to field competitive teams in the <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Coast_Conference" title="Atlantic Coast Conference">Atlantic Coast Conference</a> and maintain modern facilities. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virginia-Virginia_Tech_rivalry&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virginia-Virginia Tech rivalry (page does not exist)">Their rivalry</a> is followed statewide. Several other universities compete in <a href="/wiki/National_Collegiate_Athletic_Association" title="National Collegiate Athletic Association">NCAA</a> <a href="/wiki/Division_I_(NCAA)" title="Division I (NCAA)">Division I</a>, particularly in the <a href="/wiki/Colonial_Athletic_Association" title="Colonial Athletic Association">Colonial Athletic Association</a>. Three <a href="/wiki/Historically_black_colleges_and_universities" title="Historically black colleges and universities">historically black schools</a> compete in the Division II <a href="/wiki/Central_Intercollegiate_Athletic_Association" title="Central Intercollegiate Athletic Association">Central Intercollegiate Athletic Association</a>, and two others compete in the Division I <a href="/wiki/Mid-Eastern_Athletic_Conference" title="Mid-Eastern Athletic Conference">Mid-Eastern Athletic Conference</a>. Several smaller schools compete in the <a href="/wiki/Old_Dominion_Athletic_Conference" title="Old Dominion Athletic Conference">Old Dominion Athletic Conference</a> and the <a href="/wiki/USA_South_Athletic_Conference" title="USA South Athletic Conference">USA South Athletic Conference</a> of NCAA Division III. The NCAA currently holds its <a href="/wiki/Division_III_(NCAA)" title="Division III (NCAA)">Division III</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=NCAA_Division_III_national_football_championship&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="NCAA Division III national football championship (page does not exist)">championships in football</a>, men's basketball, volleyball and softball in <a href="/wiki/Salem,_Virginia" title="Salem, Virginia">Salem</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-302" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-302">[302]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="State_symbols">State symbols</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Virginia_new_sign.jpg" title="File:Virginia new sign.jpg">File:Virginia new sign.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The Virginia welcome sign at the Virginia welcome center on <a href="/wiki/Interstate_95" title="Interstate 95">I-95</a> employs the state bird, the <a href="/wiki/Northern_Cardinal" title="Northern Cardinal">cardinal</a>, and the state tree and flower, the <a href="/wiki/Cornus_florida" title="Cornus florida">dogwood</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The state nickname is its oldest symbol, though it has never been made official by law. Virginia was given the title "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Dominion&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dominion (page does not exist)">Dominion</a>" by King <a href="/wiki/Charles_II_of_England" title="Charles II of England">Charles II of England</a> at the time of <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Restoration&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Restoration (page does not exist)">The Restoration</a>, because it had remained loyal to the crown during the <a href="/wiki/English_Civil_War" title="English Civil War">English Civil War</a>, and the present moniker, "Old Dominion" is a reference to that title. The other nickname, "Mother of Presidents", is also historic, as eight Virginians have served as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lists_of_United_States_Presidents_by_place_of_birth&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lists of United States Presidents by place of birth (page does not exist)">President of the United States</a>, including four of the first five.<sup id="cite_ref-factpack_203-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-factpack-203">[203]</a></sup>
</p><p>The state's motto, <i><a href="/wiki/Sic_semper_tyrannis" title="Sic semper tyrannis">Sic Semper Tyrannis</a></i>, translates from Latin as "Thus Always to Tyrants", and is used on the state seal, which is then used on the flag. While the seal was designed in 1776, and the flag was first used in the 1830s, both were made official in 1930.<sup id="cite_ref-factpack_203-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-factpack-203">[203]</a></sup> The majority of the other symbols were made official in the late 20th century.<sup id="cite_ref-303" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-303">[303]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Virginia_reel_(dance)" title="Virginia reel (dance)">Virginia reel</a> is among the <a href="/wiki/Square_dance" title="Square dance">square dances</a> classified as the <a href="/wiki/List_of_U.S._state_dances" title="List of U.S. state dances">state dance</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-eov_13-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eov-13">[13]</a></sup> Virginia currently has no <a href="/wiki/List_of_U.S._state_songs" title="List of U.S. state songs">state song</a>. In 1940, Virginia made "<a href="/wiki/Carry_Me_Back_to_Old_Virginny" title="Carry Me Back to Old Virginny">Carry Me Back to Old Virginny</a>" the state song, but it was retired in 1997 and reclassified as the state song emeritus.<sup id="cite_ref-304" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-304">[304]</a></sup> Various alternatives, including a version of "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Oh_Shenandoah&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Oh Shenandoah (page does not exist)">Oh Shenandoah</a>", have met with resistance in the <a href="/wiki/Virginia_House_of_Delegates" title="Virginia House of Delegates">Virginia House of Delegates</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-305" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-305">[305]</a></sup>
</p>
<table border="0" style="margin:auto;">

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<ul>
<li> <a href="/wiki/List_of_U.S._state_mammals" title="List of U.S. state mammals">Mammal</a>: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Townsend%27s_big-eared_bat&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Townsend's big-eared bat (page does not exist)">Virginia Big-Eared Bat</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/List_of_U.S._state_beverages" title="List of U.S. state beverages">Beverage</a>: <a href="/wiki/Milk" title="Milk">Milk</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_U.S._state_ships&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of U.S. state ships (page does not exist)">Boat</a>: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chesapeake_Bay_deadrise&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chesapeake Bay deadrise (page does not exist)">Chesapeake Bay deadrise</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/List_of_U.S._state_birds" title="List of U.S. state birds">Bird</a>: <a href="/wiki/Northern_Cardinal" title="Northern Cardinal">Cardinal</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/List_of_U.S._state_dances" title="List of U.S. state dances">Dance</a>: <a href="/wiki/Square_dance" title="Square dance">Square dancing</a>
</li>
</ul>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<ul>
<li> <a href="/wiki/List_of_U.S._state_mammals" title="List of U.S. state mammals">Dog</a>: <a href="/wiki/American_Foxhound" title="American Foxhound">American Foxhound</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/List_of_U.S._state_fish" title="List of U.S. state fish">Fish</a>: <a href="/wiki/Brook_trout" title="Brook trout">Brook trout</a>, <a href="/wiki/Striped_bass" title="Striped bass">Striped bass</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/List_of_U.S._state_flowers" title="List of U.S. state flowers">Flower</a>/<a href="/wiki/List_of_U.S._state_trees" title="List of U.S. state trees">Tree</a>: <a href="/wiki/Cornus_florida" title="Cornus florida">Dogwood</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/List_of_U.S._state_fossils" title="List of U.S. state fossils">Fossil</a>: <i><a href="/wiki/Chesapecten_jeffersonius" title="Chesapecten jeffersonius">Chesapecten jeffersonius</a></i>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/List_of_U.S._state_insects" title="List of U.S. state insects">Insect</a>: <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Tiger_Swallowtail" title="Eastern Tiger Swallowtail" class="mw-redirect">Tiger swallowtail</a>
</li>
</ul>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<ul>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_U.S._state_mottos&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of U.S. state mottos (page does not exist)">Motto</a>: <a href="/wiki/Sic_semper_tyrannis" title="Sic semper tyrannis">Sic Semper Tyrannis</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/List_of_U.S._state_nicknames" title="List of U.S. state nicknames">Nickname</a>: The Old Dominion
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_U.S._state_shells&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of U.S. state shells (page does not exist)">Shell</a>: <a href="/wiki/Eastern_oyster" title="Eastern oyster">Eastern oyster</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_U.S._state_slogans&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of U.S. state slogans (page does not exist)">Slogan</a>: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virginia_is_for_Lovers&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virginia is for Lovers (page does not exist)">Virginia is for Lovers</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_U.S._state_tartans&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of U.S. state tartans (page does not exist)">Tartan</a>: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virginia_Quadricentennial_Tartan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virginia Quadricentennial Tartan (page does not exist)">Virginia Quadricentennial</a>
</li>
</ul>
</td></tr></table>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>

</p>

</p>

</li>

</li>

</li>

</li>

</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Cite_book&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Cite book (page does not exist)">Template:Cite book</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Cite_book&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Cite book (page does not exist)">Template:Cite book</a>
</li>

<dl>
<dt>Government
</dt>
</dl>
<ul>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://portal.virginia.gov/">State Government website</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://legis.state.va.us/">Virginia General Assembly</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.courts.state.va.us/">Virginia's Judicial system</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://legis.state.va.us/Laws/search/Constitution.htm">Constitution of Virginia</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.genealogyinc.com/virginia/government/">Virginia State and County Government Websites</a>
</li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dt>Tourism and recreation
</dt>
</dl>
<ul>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.virginia.org/">Virginia Tourism Website</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.dcr.virginia.gov/state_parks/state_park.shtml">Virginia State Parks</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.nps.gov/history/nr/travel/VAmainstreet/">Virginia Main Street Communities Travel</a>
</li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dt>Culture and history
</dt>
</dl>
<ul>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.vahistorical.org/">Virginia Historical Society</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://virginiaindians.pwnet.org/index.php">Virginia's First People</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://xroads.virginia.edu/~HYPER/VAGuide/frame.html">WPA Guide to the Old Dominion</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.lva.virginia.gov/">Library of Virginia</a>
</li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dt>Maps and Demographics
</dt>
</dl>
<ul>

</li>

</li>
